This project is part of the Open Data for Development (OD4D) program, a global network using data to promote social good. The OD4D network is funded by IDRC, Global Affairs Canada, and the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation.

The Open Data for Development (OD4D) program has advanced leadership in the Global South to showcase how sharing and using data drives accountability and transparency, supports social innovation and entrepreneurship, and informs more inclusive practices. This project will fund key activities related to knowledge translation and dissemination, learning, and program evaluation. Among the activities will be an evaluation to assess the programming impact of OD4D III, support for an international conference in Nairobi, and support for the design and development of the OD4D website and key research products. The majority of the work will support uptake of key lessons and research from the Open Data for Development network to build capacity and promote research uptake in research and policy circles. 

This project builds on the Open Data for Development (OD4D) program, a global network using data to promote social good. OD4D is supported by IDRC, Global Affairs Canada, and The William and Flora Hewlett Foundation.

Despite the positive potential and relative progress of open data for development, there are still gaps in creating and sharing high quality, timely, relevant, and accessible data in developing countries. Past research on Francophone Africa has highlighted the lack of capacity among data producers, particularly governments, to release high quality, timely data about public issues. Many countries still lack foundational legislation, such as right-to-information laws, or a lack of political will to enforce them. There are also concerns about data sharing, power, and privacy. Further, in many cases there is a lack of capacity amongst actors in understanding the potential of sharing data or technical practices in releasing digital open data. 

Another major challenge is a lack of resources to address capacity and skills gaps, as many resources are not available in French and local languages. These capacity challenges have a negative effect on the release of quality open data about government services such as justice, government budgets and spending, agriculture, education, and more. These challenges contribute to a resulting lack of use of open data, despite demand from a range of stakeholders. Nevertheless, where data is available, useful innovations are emerging, such as mapping aid data to increase the efficiency of service delivery. In addition, there have been notable advancements in assessing spending and delivery outcomes on education and health, monitoring public procurement to reduce corruption and increase efficiency of public spending, and driving innovations and economic growth through community mapping and digital innovations.

This project will focus on strengthening the environment for open and shared data to be used for sustainable development in Francophone Africa. It will support multidisciplinary applied research, capacity building, and innovations to support the release and use of data by governments and intermediaries such as technologists, journalists, academics, civil society groups, and rights organizations. The project will also focus on driving use of data through data challenges and mini-grants and scaling past innovations such as portals on open journalism, aid spending, and more.

The proposed transaction consists of a senior secured A Loan of up to US$30 million to ODATA S.A. (ODATA or the Company), a Brazilian carrier neutral Multi-Tenant data center (MTDC) operator with three data centers in Brazil. The facility will have 8-year tenor including a 2-year grace period. The funds will be used to support the Companys US$78.5 million capital expenditure program requirements over the next 3 years (2020-2023) for the expansion of the 3 existing DC in Brazil (the Project).
Online Platforms & Databases
Hub 3: Electoral Databases & Statistics
Interface Development for the Dataset on Post-Conflict Constitution-Building Processes
Online Platforms & Databases
Online Platforms & Databases
Updating the GEPPAL database

Following an increasing awareness of migration in the international arena, it has become imperative to disseminate accurate and unbiased migration information, which is built on a correct understanding and interpretation of migration data. This in turn fosters an environment of non-discrimination that is inclusive of diversity in gender, back ground and migration status, in ever-changing and increasingly heterogeneous communities. Important enablers of such environments include universities and academic institutions, together with the expression of civil society members, as these are well-trusted transmitters of important information into the public sphere. As the UN Migration Agency, IOM aims to support such dissemination through the Migration Literacy Enhancement Advance Non-Discrimination (M-LEARN) project. M-LEARN aims at embedding migration data guidance into higher educational systems. A new curriculum on migration data and statistics will be developed and rolled out. This will be achieved through the production of a university course on migration data, including a course handbook, which will be taught for the first time-ever in French in Morocco and Tunisia, and of a related online module which will be rolled out to a wider audience.

Southern Africa is home to different types of migration, consisting of countries of origin such as Lesotho, Malawi and Zimbabwe and destination countries such as South Africa and Botswana, with South Africa being the biggest recipient country. Despite the high volume of population mobility within the region, there is dearth of data on the number of international migrants in Southern African Development Community. In countries where data on international migration is available, the data are fragmented, and non-comparable between the countries. The lack of data on migration in the region has made it difficult to formulate evidence-based migration policy development, design and evaluation in the region. The proposed project aims to support the ongoing efforts to strengthen migration data at the national and regional level. This overall objective will be achieved through the implementation of several components to strengthen the capacities of national institutions in the areas of migration data collection and management. National consultations will take place in each of the 5 countries to ensure early engagement of national actors and create the space for these actors to determine the scope of the project and the development of subsequent components.
The project aims at supporting the Government of Ghana in mainstreaming Migration in the national census.

Since 2014, IOM's Missing Migrants Project has collected and analysed data on more than 32,000 migrant deaths and disappearances worldwide. However, data on missing migrants tends to be uneven, as there is far more media coverage and reporting of deaths occurring in the Mediterranean region than other parts of the world. Few data on migrant deaths are recorded in several regions with large volumes of irregular migrants, including much of Africa, Asia, and Latin America, despite reports that these pose many dangers to migrants. Gathering more and better-quality data on missing migrants is especially important at a time when states are discussing how best to achieve safer and more orderly migration. In order to overcome the challenges of collecting data on deaths during migration, the proposed project will improve upon the Missing Migrants Project's existing data sources and strengthen partnerships with relevant state and non-state actors in those regions where there is little information on migrant deaths and disappearances.

The project will strengthen the identification and protection of trafficking victims (TiP) in Indonesia, which will then contribute to the eradication of all forms of modern-day slavery in Indonesia. Stemming from this purpose, IOM in close collaboration with the National and Local Anti-Trafficking Task Forces, will continue to advance the efforts to improve TiP data collection, reporting, and sharing, as well as increasing victims' access to government services.

IOM will convene a workshop with selected representatives from Bali Process Member states involved in the technical experts group on return and reintegration (TEG-RR) to provide officials with tools and data that help capture the challenges associated with the management of sustainable returns and reintegration, and addressing the needs of return migrants. These tools and key data outlining sustainable reintegration practices will be compiled based on the monitoring of returnees in 4 Bali Process Member States (Pakistan, Viet Nam, Nepal, Mongolia) in a policy brief that will sustain the discussion within this project, and forthcoming Bali process meetings.

The objective of this action is to contribute to improving living conditions of vulnerable populations in Venezuela through the provision of multi-sector humanitarian assistance and mobility tracking operations. To achieve this objective, IOM is: 1) Providing shelter assistance and access to basic services to people in need in Venezuela including infrastructure rehabilitation of five temporary accommodation centres, provision of equipment, direct assistance through the provision of accommodation and food, and basic services such as sanitation facilities, as well as the provision of training on shelter management to local partners; 2) Providing non-food items and hygiene kits to beneficiaries of the temporary accommodation centres as well as to five vulnerable host communities in five states of Venezuela; 3) Providing life-saving information related to access to documentation, prevention of trafficking and smuggling, gender-based violence and other forms of exploitation and abuse, and facilitating access to protection services through referrals inside Venezuela; 4) Providing information on population movements, needs and vulnerabilities through Mobility Tracking Matrix (MTM); and 5) Providing personal protective equipment and institutional kits to, respectively, personnel of medical facilities and 22 government established centres for quarantine (PASI), in order to prevent COVID-19.

The project aims to provide the country with a functional border management system which will effectively record the country’s entry/exit, and at the same time verify that each passenger is not in the alert lists databases like Interpol, as well as regional and national listings.
The project aims to empower communities and local leadership to identify the drivers of conflict and displacement and implement activities aiming at addressing all dimensions of human insecurity.

The project will provide the IOM border migration information and data analysis systems (MIDAS) to all five of Nigeria's international airports that operate year-round. MIDAS at the air borders will enable the immigration service to fully integrate INTERPOL and national watch list data into the air passenger screening system and will also enable them to implement advanced passenger information system, which is anticipated to be required by International Civil Aviation Organization starting in 2018. The implementation of MIDAS at the air borders should also have a positive effect on facilitating passenger arrival and departure, and in that regard contribute to the government's overall priority of improving ease of doing business in Nigeria.

Project will  contribute to institutional strengethening and capacity development that will lead to remittance and other flowsto increase financial service provision to marginal areas and increase household involvement in financial systems

The overall objective of this project is to increase food security throughout South Sudan by supporting effective and efficient food assistance, resource allocation, distribution and thematic analysis related to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees.

This project contributes to increasing food security throughout South Sudan by supporting effective and efficient food assistance, resource allocation, and distribution. The project works towards the achievement of two key outcomes: Improved understanding of food security, livelihoods, and multi-sector household needs in major urban areas in South Sudan to guide evidence-based programming and increased accountability over resource allocation through biometric authentication at distribution sites (protection of civilians sites (PoCs), collective centres) and regular maintenance of biometric registration database and improved data management.

While the Western Balkan (WB) route was closed in March 2016, the region continued to see mixed migration flows towards the European Union (EU), mostly moving through irregular channels.  While in 2015-2016 the main countries facing these mixed migration movements were North Macedonia and Serbia, since 2018 migrants have been increasingly transiting through Albania, Montenegro and Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH). Many migrants have been left stranded along the route and consequently facing a number of vulnerabilities. Key concerns in BiH remain the provision of adequate accommodation facilities and capacity gaps in the Service for Foreigners Affairs (SFA) related to the identification, screening and registration of migrants. Regionally, there remains a lack of reliable data on the total number of migrants present in the WB outside of official reception facilities. The overall objective of this proposed intervention is to strengthen capacities of authorities to have a more evidence based, protection sensitive and sustainable community-based migration response.
Project focuses on building the Border Management Capacity Of Nigerian Immigration Service (NIS) by strengthening the Migration Information Data System (MIDAS) operating at borders in Nigeria

This project aims to improve migration management in Libya and strengthen the capacity of Libyan authorities to manage borders more efficiently. Particularly, this initiative aims at building and enhancing the capacity of Libya’s border management authorities to efficiently manage cross-border movements through the deployment of the IOM's Migration Information and Data Analysis System (MIDAS). In addition IOM will provide specific training activities for border and immigration officials to be fully competent in using MIDAS and to enhance border management capabilities.

The objective of the project is to contribute to the Government of Nigeria enhancing border security and travel facilitation through centralized data architecture with the IOM’s Migration Information and Analysis System (MIDAS) platform and inter-agency cooperation. As a result, the Government of Nigeria will facilitate faster, safer and more reliable traveller processing at air borders through strengthened national data architecture, relevant legal framework and inter-agency cooperation. Also, relevant government agencies in Nigeria, will manage to conduct secondary inspection at international airports through a common investigative approach based on appropriate legal framework and strengthened inter-agency cooperation.

The project aims to enhance Nigeria's migration and border management capacity and achieve an increase in identification of serious transnational organized crime cases by enabling the further use of operational data; integration of INTERPOL databases and other relevant watchlists; and strengthened capacity of individual NIS officers. Under this project, approximately 60 NIS officers are expected to benefit from the planned training opportunities.

In 2016, IOM introduced the Migration Information and Data Analysis System (MIDAS) in Nigeria to strengthen the Federal Government of Nigeria's ability to process individuals' identity when entering or exiting the country. This complex endeavour has been continuously supported by multiple donors and has contributed to the fortification of the country's border, especially in the north along the Niger borderline. The same cannot be said for the country's southern border shared with Cameroon as it has been experiencing a recent influx of driven by the Anglophone Crisis in northwest and south-west regions of Cameroon. Based on the achievements of the programme so far and to enhance the capacity of the Government to process migrants at its international borders in Akwa Ibom State, IOM in coordination with the Nigerian Immigration Service (NIS) will either install or repair and upgrade the MIDAS system at two strategically located seaports in the state as well as the State Command Office.

Building on the success as well as lessons learned of the previous phase which ended in July 2019, the proposed project aims to further assist the Government of Nigeria, particularly through NIS, in expanding the foreigner registration across the country while ensuring the quality and interoperability of captured biometric data through providing standardization support. Privacy and data protection principles will be fully incorporated throughout the project planning and implementation.

This project is designed as a joint UN project. The UN project team will engage other UN agencies through the UN Task Force to advance essential event registration and other related initiatives to facilitate access to financial services, following agency mandates outlined in the UNCT Operational Guidelines. IOM role will focus on updating standard operation procedure for linking registration and legal identity confirmation for refugee, migrant, displaced and stateless populations.

The project aims to set up mechanisms for harmonizing, consolidating and sharing of labour migration data to inform policy solutions amongst countries, to enhance cooperation and reach evidence-based and harmonized labour migration policies in the East and Horn of Africa (EHOA) in coherence with national and regional priorities for sustainable development. The selected EHOA countries (Kenya, Somalia and Uganda) are co-signatories to the Regional Ministerial Forum on Migration (RMFM) Communique and Call for Action. The project responds to the RMFM Communique signed at the regional level and its Call for Action and the interests of the co signatory EHOA countries as the data is mentioned specifically under the regional cooperation section as well as under Objectives 3 and 4. Areas of engagement will target interventions on regulation and enforcement, regional cooperation, migration governance and policy, as well as protection of migrant workers.

The Government of India (GoI) and the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) are invested in strengthening the availability of comprehensive labour migration data to facilitate gainful labour migration for aspiring migrants and support national socioeconomic recovery. The project's objective is to contribute to improving access to labour migration opportunities for aspiring Indian migrants through strengthened migration management frameworks. The project will conduct a thorough needs assessment of existing data gaps and needs, develop and equip the MEA with a comprehensive migration data management strategy, and pilot communication materials and surveys to inform migrant workers on the benefits of submitting data voluntarily. The project will also conduct and equip the MEA with research on post-COVID-19 emerging labour markets in Northern and Eastern Europe and the elderly care-giving sector, and facilitate bilateral migration dialogues and sector-specific consultations with key stakeholders.

This project will support the government of Nepal to introduce a comprehensive database which will serve as a primary reference point for migration health related information collected from all different information management system of the government and non-government institutions.

The project will help Moroccan authorities reinforce the production, the analysis and the diffusion mechanisms of migration data both at a national and African level. In line with the 2030 Agenda for sustainable development, the project meets the challenges Morocco is facing in terms of migration and its place at the regional level. Moreover, it will contribute to promote gender equality through the reinforcement of gender-disaggregated data collection, analysis and use enabling the development and the implementation of gender-sensitive policies.

The project aims to inform and strengthen both shorter-term humanitarian and programmatic responses and longer-term policy decisions on environmental migration and disaster displacement through the provision of evidence and verifiable data. The project will develop a national profile incorporating quantitative data and three case studies on different types of regions – mountainous regions, cattle corridor, and lowlands. This profile will provide a guidance for policymakers and humanitarian partners on environmental migration and displacement.

In the face of increasing climate risks including more frequent and extreme droughts, the Republic of the Marshall Islands (RMI) requires greater investment in water related efforts. The project is a small component of the larger UNDP Addressing Climate Vulnerability in the Water Sector (ACWA) in the Marshall Islands project currently in its initial stages. The 7-year project (2019-2026) is originally funded by the Green Climate Fund (GCF) and implemented by UNDP. The RMI Baseline Survey Project will contribute to RMI's ability to adapt to increasing climate risks, particularly droughts, by conducting surveys to substantiate baselines to reflect the community demographics and rainwater harvesting system quality in communities and validate information gaps between the ACWA project formulation and implementation. IOM will work in close coordination with UNDP and the RMI Environment Protection Agency (EPA) throughout the project.

The International Forum on Migration Statistics (IFMS) is a unique global platform that brings together people from national statistical offices, international organizations, non-governmental organizations and academia to discussion how to improve data on migration in all its dimensions.  The second edition of the IFMS will be led by IOM (and co-organized with the Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) and the UN Department of Economic and Social Affairs (UN DESA)), and hosted by the African Union (AU) and the Egyptian Government, from 19-21 January 2020 in Cairo, Egypt.

This project supports the operational costs of the International Forum on Migration Statistics (IFMS). The IFMS is a unique, global platform devoted to improving data on migration in all its dimensions. In the frame of Egypt’s chairmanship to the African Union (AU), the second IFMS will be hosted in Egypt, Cairo from 20-21 January 2020.  For the first time, there will also be an additional, third day with workshops for data capacity development. IOM is leading the organization and the implementation of the Forum, in partnership with UN DESA and OECD. The overall objective of this project is that migration data dialogue is improved globally.

Migration plays a central role in the national development of Turkmenistan. However, due to the lack of capacities to collect, analyze and use statistical data, migration has not been factored in as a key variable within the national development plans and policies until today. The objective of the proposed project is to contribute to strengthened migration governance by the Government of Turkmenistan through evidence-based policy making. The project will aim to strengthen the capacity of the government in collecting and analyzing statistical data on migration, as well as their capacity to develop evidence-based policies. The first output will be delivered through a series of training sessions on gender-sensitive data collection and data analysis methodologies. The second output will be addressed through a series of workshops on evidence-based policy making for mid-level government professionals engaged in migration management and development of national sectoral policies.

The complexity of mixed migration involving Ethiopia and Ethiopians calls for a solid and well-rounded approach to migration governance, including the collection, processing and dissemination of migration data and related information on migration, so that the benefits of migration can be effectively harnessed and challenges addressed. The project aims to contribute to the Government of Ethiopia's efforts to improve migration governance and uphold migrants' human rights, though strengthened migration coordination mechanisms and data management systems.

The lack of comprehensive data on migration in the Southern Africa Development Community (SADC) region has made it difficult to formulate evidence-based migration policy development. In response to the need for relevant, reliable, and disaggregated migration data, IOM in partnership with the SADC Member States and key stakeholders launched the Regional Migration Data Hub for Southern Africa (RMDHub) in 2017. The RMDHub will generate information on migration trends, patterns and dynamics through the collection and analysis of migration data to advance evidence-based migration policies at the national and regional levels. The proposed project aims to support the ongoing efforts to strengthen migration data at the national and regional levels.

The Global Migration Data Portal is a one-stop-shop website providing access to and guidance on a wide range of existing migration data. The Portal began as a pilot project in 2016, implemented by IOM’s Global Migration Data Analysis Centre (GMDAC), and was followed by a second phase, during which the Portal was more fully developed before being launched at the German Federal Foreign Office on 15 December 2017. Since its launch, the Portal has harnessed interest within the field of migration, and has had broad media coverage globally, particularly via the Associated Press and the Washington Post. In this third phase, the overall objective and focus will be to expand and scale up the content on the Portal, while also maintaining and updating the existing content.  By doing so, the Portal becomes more accessible and is in turn used as a tool to inform migration policy.

In response to DFID's business case for the Safety, Support and Solutions programme, the programme reflects a route-based approach, focusing on the Central Mediterranean Route (CMR), and covers 10 countries as well as central IOM units (DTM, LHD, GMDAC, MAD, MCD). The overall aim of this multi-year, multi-country project is to contribute asafer and more orderly migration along the Central Mediterranean Route (CMR), resulting in fewer deaths and less suffering along migratory rules.

One of the most apparent shortfalls in the current migration data space until recently was the absence of a comprehensive, one-stop-shop for migration information and data, both in the form of timely textual analysis, including the strengths and weaknesses of the data sources, and, in particular, for data access and analysis purposes. Many public policy communities, over the years, have suffered from a diffuse and confusing approach to information. At the same time some areas account for very advanced information. Economic development data is available, for example, on dozens of websites, as is information on public health issues. Since the launch of the Global Migration Data Portal, from herein after referred to as the Portal, in December 2017, the Portal has pursued a long-term strategy to become the primary point of departure for all stakeholders interested in migration data and to become an exchange platform for the international community of migration experts and agencies developed by IOM's Global Migration Data Analysis Centre, in partnership with key international experts and UN agencies, the portal strives to meet three goals: it must be useful, comprehensive andtimely. In this context, 'useful' means that the content is valuable to users, and that they will want to come back frequently for updates. 'Comprehensive' means that the Portal covers the widest range of countries and migration topics possible. This means that the Portal is not limited, as are other migration data-related websites, to a certain region or topic. Timely' means that the Portal uploads new migration data indicators as they are released, publishes blogs that cover emerging topics and videos with migration experts to explain ongoing migration topics in Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America. In order to become a global reference point on migration data, the Portal must be expanded.

The main objective of the project is to contribute to building the migration data governance framework of Georgia. The Unified Migration Analytical System (UMAS), an up-to-date national infrastructure for migration data analysis, is currently functioning in test regime and hassecured, received, and processed multiple datasets from the main administrative data sources in the country. Despite the modern technicalsolutions, a lack of analytical capacities impedes execution of the mainpurpose of the system, the actual analysis of technically sorted and processed migration data. The project plans to address challenges at the strategic and executive levels.

This project seeks to strengthen migration-related and humanitarian interventions and collaboration with national emergency responders in Chad to address the needs of migrants and mobile populations, keeping in mind the cross-border and regional implications of the crises affecting Chad, and targeting responses accordingly. This project provides a compelling evidence base to inform the response and policies by providing a comprehensive analysis of migration flows and routes, migrants’ profiles and protection needs generated through the collection of primary data in Chad.

The Multi Cluster Locations Assessment (MCLA) is going beyond location-level key informant interviews to gather more granular information on the humanitarian needs of specific population groups directly from households. Through household level interviews, the MCLA identifies individual household level vulnerabilities and humanitarian needs. This data contributes towards enhancing humanitarian needs severity analyses to inform humanitarian programming in 2020. The 2019 MCLA will mirror the 2018 exercise in scope and scale. The goal of the assessment is to identify household level vulnerabilities and humanitarian needs through household-level (HH) interviews in all 333 districts in Yemen. The MCLA also provides some clarity on the humanitarian context in Yemen by assessing the biggest challenges faced by affected populations when trying to access basic services and fulfil fundamental needs.

The project will develop the capacity of governments and other stakeholders to collect, manage, and use high-quality, comparable, primary data on human trafficking to develop the evidence base policy and programming.

In alignment with the WHO's Global Humanitarian Response Plan (GHRP) and the Afghanistan COVID-19 Multi-Sector Humanitarian Country Plan, IOM is implementing its Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) program in Afghanistan with the aim to contribute to the COVID-19 response. In particular, IOM's DTM teams contribute to the implementation of activities under three areas of intervention: risk communication and community engagement, surveillance, and points of entry.

The objective of this project is to contribute to evidence-based policy-making and informed decision making by providing clear, reliable and easily accessible migration-related data since such data is currently scarce, not reliable and not readily available as it is scattered across different institutions.  The project will establish a government coordination mechanism through a technical working group to support the development of the migration profile, strengthen the capacity of the government stakeholders in data collection and develop standard operating procedures for data collection.  The project will also produce a data mapping report and develop a comprehensive migration profile. The activities through the inter-ministerial coordination, data collection, training, knowledge sharing, and the government secondment will ensure the creation of a migration profile that can be sustainably maintained and updated by the involved stakeholders beyond the project closure.

The project will enable the protection of identified victims of trafficking (VOTs) which will then contribute to the eradication of all forms of modern-day slavery in Indonesia. Stemming from this purpose, in close collaboration with National and Local Anti-Trafficking Task Force, IOM will work towards delivering a long-term impact in establishing accurate baselines, increasing the identification of VOTs, and enabling VOTs to have better access to government services.  The project will achieve the above envisioned results by improving data collection/reporting procedure and to pilot the improved standard operating procedures in the four selected provinces of East Nusa Tenggara, West Java, West Kalimantan, and North Kalimantan. Further to this, IOM will support the enhancement of civil society organizations, government and non-government service providers’ capacities in providing assistance to victims of trafficking.

IOM is providing humanitarian post-arrival assistance through its cross-border response programme in Afghanistan, to vulnerable undocumented returnees; strengthening the provision of cross-border health services and establishing active case finding teams at all four major border crossing points where IOM already runs clinics to detect and treat tuberculosis.  IOM will continue to perform Displacement Tracking Matrix mobility assessments in cross-border provinces in response to ongoing displacement, predominantly as a result of drought and conflict. IOM is also providing an essential evidence base for health, humanitarian and health partners to inform the selection of priority communities in most need of health, essential services, and community stabilization assistance.

The project will develop the capacity of governments and other stakeholders to collect, manage, and use high-quality, comparable, primary data on vulnerable migrants, including victims of human trafficking to develop the evidence base.

This project will contribute to strengthening Government of Moldova (GoM) legislation, strategies and response plans to prevent violence and improve access to quality services for youth victims of violence in Moldova. To this end, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and IOM will lead the design and implementation of the Moldova youth health and well-being survey Sanatatea Mea, a quantitative study designed to estimate the prevalence of violence against children and youth, as well as to identify risk and protective factors for violence, and examine health consequences of violence. Sanatatea Mea findings will provide evidence for the GoM, donors, and civil society in Moldova to strengthen legislation and design effective strategies and plans to prevent violence and improve access to quality services for victims of violence.

The proposed project aims to enhance regional convergence of data collection, analysis and dissemination through the implementation of three interconnected pillars of activities: I) to undertake in-depth studies on factors shaping different groups of migrants’ decisions to leave their country and chose a route and destination, with a particular focus on forced mobility (year 1) and II) to coordinate and strengthen cross-country and cross-regional data collection and data analysis which links information about mobility patterns with findings regarding the underlying factors that shape migration decisions, seeking to link debates on forced, irregular and regular migration, as well as making the connection between internal and cross-border mobility dynamics, with a strong gender component (year 1-3), and III) to strengthen IOM’s cooperation with OCHA-Hoxton further enhance data interoperability and information sharing mechanisms (year 1-3). This stands to contribute to a fuller and more comprehensive understanding of human mobility patterns that can inform operational actors as well as policy makers and academia on required actions to address and mitigate root causes and to enhance avenues for migration that mutually benefits migrants and society. The project will build upon commitments by other donors, most notably DFID, which is supporting IOM activities to foster a greater understanding of migration flows in Afghanistan, Pakistan, Syria, Turkey, and along the Western Balkans and Mediterranean route, and is initiating a new project to support the establishment of flow monitoring points in Western and Central Africa.

Through this project, IOM aims at increasing food security throughout South Sudan by supporting effective and efficient food assistance resource allocation and distribution. This project enables IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) to establish biometric authentication stations at the World Food Programme (WFP) food distribution sites, and conduct routine biometric maintenance, as well as additional biometric registrations and verification exercises in order to drive more targeted food distribution, maximize operational impact and support more effective and efficient resource mobilization, whilst strengthening partnership between the two organizations for the benefit of the wider humanitarian community.

In response to critical levels of internal displacement in Afghanistan caused by what is being described as the worst drought in the country indecades, through this action IOM’s Displacement Tracking Matrix (DTM) will continue to implement flow monitoring to identify and register the newly arriving drought-affected internally displaced persons (IDP) caseload in Herat City, as well as in Qala-e-Naw in Badghis. In addition, IOM will share the information with humanitarian partners to facilitate onward registration of newly arriving IDPs into humanitarian assistance programmes and expedite subsequent delivery of assistance. Additionally, DTM will also continue to track the outflow of IDPs returning to their places of origin or into secondary displacement as well as conduct return intention surveys in locations of displacement toidentify the intentions, motivations, needs and concerns. This will enable partners to better integrate the concerns and requirements of potential returnees into return packages and into return strategies in areas of origin to deliver sustainable return solutions.

While organizations are increasingly relying on data in order to drive decision making, data systems must be user focused. This project aims to increase access to and use of actionable information on the outputs and impact of cornerstone GBV programming to inform organizational responses

This project represents the core funding for the T4SD database and IT systems (Sustainability Map and its related modules) that is provided by the German government W1 contribution.The 2018-2019 project activities included:1. Identification, referencing and updating of standards in the T4SD global database.2. Improving the taxonomy of the the T4SD database and data entry tool (DET) functionality.3. Organisation and implementation of the 5th and 6th annual T4SD Forum, as well as any other relevant awareness-raising events (2019).4. Maintaining and improving the Sustainability Map platform. In 2020, the project activities will largely mirror the activities in 2018-2019, as the funding is dedicated to supporting T4SD's core work in providing transparency and awareness of voluntary sustainability standards, namely through the T4SD Global Database of VSS and the related Sustainability Map platform. In 2020, the activities will be centered around:1. A complete update of the taxonomy of the T4SD Database and the data entry tool (DET), resulting in a 'DET10'.2. Identification, referencing and updating of standards in the T4SD Database.3. Altering the IT infrastructure underpinning the Sustainability Map platform to offer updated functionalities to users.4. Organisation of the 7th T4SD Forum, similarly to the 5th and 6th edition.ITC/T4SD is uniquely suited to provide this data to all actors in the value chain from upstream producers to BSOs, to downstream buyers and industry associations – accessible to all via a Global Public Good solution. T4SD will therefore continue implementing similar activities in 2021 as it has in the previous years, to ensure continuity and highest possible quality of the relevant standards’ data and the database underpinning it. Expansion and maintenance of the good usability of the database and its public interface will remain big priorities for the project in 2021. In addition, new initiatives will be added in 2021: increased efforts in enhancing the transparency on VSS globally, namely through the roll-out of the T4SD Executive programme to MSMEs, developing new features of the Standards Map and hosting an event to mark the Standards Map's 10 year anniversary in serving its global stakeholders. The project will also contribute to the development of the new umbrella market linkages sustainability platform, co-funded by W2 project B036 (Sustainability Gateway). The team will also plan for its annual T4SD Forum (or, the Good Trade Summit) under this project. The Outcome of this project:  Business and trade community have a better understanding of voluntary sustainability standards (VSS), is linked the T4SD programme's theory of change outcomes A and B across all beneficiaries (policymakers, TISIs, MSMEs, and market partners). The project's outputs directly contribute to scaling the T4SD W2 results, as the W2 B036 project co-funds and uses the core T4SD platforms for its outputs and outcomes (Sustainability Gateway / Sustainability Map).

The project aims to provide EU decision makers with solid evidence base on women's participation in extra-EU trade in services, shaped to be used as input for enhanced inclusion of the gender dimension in free trade agreements. This will facilitate the adoption of trade policy instruments conducive to increasing women's engagement in trade in services. The work entails: documenting the gender-structure of EU-based firms exporting services (in terms of management/ownership/employment); and, identifying the obstacles that hinder women's engagement in extra EU-trade in services. The method developed in the framework of the project can be replicated in other countries, and it can thus play a crucial role in closing the data gap on women's participation in international trade. The main component of the project is a survey that contributes to better understand the participation of women in extra-EU trade in services (in terms of employment, management and ownership of exporting companies) and the challenges faced by women when engaging in international trade in services. The survey will provide the results of relevance at the EU level and at the sector level.

The purpose of the ITC SME Competitiveness Survey (SMECS) is to increase awareness on issues related to SME Competitiveness through three key channels: collecting firm level information on SME competitiveness in partnership with trade and investment supporting institutions (TISIs) ; disseminating knowledge and evidence on SME competitiveness through the ITC SME Competitiveness Outlook (SMECO) and; enabling ITC Managers of projects that aim at enhancing SME competitiveness to conduct harmonized needs and impact assessments. Specifically, the overall outcome of the project will be achieved by building capacity of TISIs to collect SME Competitiveness data and assess them; by producing quantitative and qualitative analysis on SME Competitiveness and widely disseminating this information through ITC SME Competitiveness Outlook; and finally, by providing guidance to ITC Project Managers on the use of SMECS for project needs and impact assessment and to support the tailoring of SMECS to specific project requirements.

While organizations are increasingly relying on data in order to drive decision making, data systems must be user focused. This project aims to increase access to and use of actionable information on the outputs and impact of cornerstone GBV programming to inform organizational responses

1. To help the organization acquire enough information for program up scaling best practices to new areas 2. Piloting mobile application in data collection and real-time transmission in remote setups.
Collaboration between The Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health (JHSPH) and The Guttmacher Institute on abortion measurement activities in Ghana.

The objective of the project is the creation of a centralised online open source of information relating to disability by country, using data generated by governments and other actors, and preparation of an initial summary / analysis of global disability statistics for DFID’s Disability Summit in July 2018. The three main components of the Disability Data Global Mapping and Assessment project are: 1. Research: • Identify and review latest key statistics (in consultation with DFID) in a defined number of domains – (health, education, employment, etc.) and demographics (age, sex, geography – urban/rural) by country; • Identify other non-governmental sources of data on disability. 2. Online portal development • Create a comprehensive accessible web platform that will bring all relevant data together, with particular emphasis on review of prevalence data and key outcome indicators allowing disaggregation from National Statistics Offices (NSOs) on key disability indicators – concentrating on censuses, and nationally representative surveys. 3. Data analysis and dissemination • Review online data with particular focus on data relevant to SDG indicators • Working – in consultation with DFID – On developing a plan for the sustainability of the portal that would be established through DFID’s funding Jan-June 2018.Develop and publish a report with key findings based on an initial analysis and summary of global disability statistics to share at the DFID Disability Summit. • The current project will be run with the objective of compiling a viable website that can be presented as a product at the upcoming DFID Summit in July. In the coming months, LCD will explore opportunities for longer term funding for the project that would allow it to continue beyond the Sept 2018.
Malaria Indicator Survey Study - Reimbursable Service Contract in South Sudan (funded by PSI through Global Fund)
Malaria Indicator Survey Study - Reimbursable Service Contract in South Sudan (funded by PSI through Global Fund) [South Sudan]

The significant reduction of malaria morbidity and mortality in Myanmar is threatened by a number of factors. The largest of these threats is the emergence of drug resistant malaria parasites along the international border areas, including the Myanmar-Thailand and Myanmar-China borders as well as in some areas in central Myanmar. However, to date no malaria surveys have been conducted at national scale to assess coverage of key malaria indicators. Although efforts are being made to improve the health information system in Myanmar, malaria data remain incomplete with regards to geographical coverage (past surveys did not fully capture hard-to-access areas), completeness, and coverage of high-risk groups.  To respond to this need, the National Malaria Control Programme will lead in conducting a national malaria indicator survey in 2015 with Malaria Consortium as the technical lead and funding support from the President?s Malaria Initiative, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, the Three Millennium Development Goal Fund (3MDG), GFATM and other partners. The results of this survey will help to prioritise malaria services more effectively to areas of greatest malaria burden and provide baseline malaria data to support future assessments of the impact of all malaria-related activities nationwide, as well as for future strategic planning. Additionally, it is hoped that the malaria survey will provide up-to-date information on malaria prevalence within each area of the country, enabling the Ministry of Health to determine if its current risk stratification is still reliable.

Mercy Corps have been requested by DFID to manage pass-through finding to Shujaaz, a national organisation to conduct media outreach on COVID-19 prevention targeting youth. 

Mercy Corps has no activities to complete under this programme beyond partner management. 

Programme Impact: Kenya's youth population and adults, especially in urban low-income households, can make informed decisions related to the Coronavirus prevention and control.

Malawi II - Access To Markets Projects - Baseline Data Collection activity: Compact Development Funding (CDF) is used pre-compact for key project preparation work such as the feasibility and environmental impact studies, engineering designs, baseline surveys, financial management and procurement technical assistance, and other specialized analysis to help MCC determine the final suitability and scope of investments, costs, implementation risks, and mitigation measures.

Nederlandse bijdrage voor een tweede periode van 3 jaar 2020-2023 aan het Centre for Humanitarian Data, een cen-trum dat door UNOCHA is geopend in Den Haag. De missie van het centrum is het verhogen van het gebruik en de im-pact van data in de humanitaire sector.

The project will facilitate countries to monitor biomass production and evapotranspiration and to assess land and water productivity in rainfed and irrigated agriculture by using innovative state of the art Remote Sensing and Information and Communication Technologies. Based on this information, stakeholders at different scales will be able to obtain sustainably increased and secure crop yields with a reduced impact on available freshwater resources and the environment in a changing climate.

To support low- and middle-income countries to tackle antimicrobial resistance (AMR) through improving surveillance capacity. Projects funded through Fleming Fund will benefit people in low- and middle-income countries, where the burden of drug resistant infection is greater.

Through the country and regional grants (in West Africa, East and Southern Africa, South Asia and South East Asia) and the fellowships programme the Fleming Fund will: build laboratory capacity for diagnosis; collect data on drug resistance, drug quality, drug use and the burden of disease associated with AMR; enable the sharing of data relevant to AMR locally, regionally, and internationally; encourage the application of data to promote the rational use of antimicrobials; shape a sustainable system for AMR surveillance and data sharing; and increase national leadership in addressing AMR.

Data collection through documentary reviews, in-depth interviews in the sampled ministries( Ministry of finance and PMORALG and selected Municipalities and Town Councils ( Kinondoni, Ilemela and Ilala Municipalities; Tunduma, Kigoma Ujiji, Kasulu, Tanga and  Korogwe Town Council)

The purpose of this project is to improve the income position of Indonesian nutmeg and mace farmers (male and female) in the value chains of Verstegen Spices and Sauces, as this is key to engage farmers in long-term entrepreneurial relationships and to create higher standards of social and environmental sustainability in the production and consumption of nutmeg and mace.Since Verstegen’s leverage to directly influence the purchase price is limited, the proposed intervention is an innovative online transparency platform, that allows for new income generation through tracing products and collecting product information and other relevant data within the influence of Verstegen and its supply partners. Data is one of the most valuable commodities on earth, far surpassing nutmeg or mace in market size.  A lot of data is generated during the production of nutmeg and mace and 'harvesting' this data to be 'processed' and used in the value chain brings great potential value. Smallholder farmers, who hardly produce any data whatsoever, currently underutilize this value. Monetization of data required for supply chain transparency and product traceability data in particular, and for internal and external business processes in general, presents a powerful opportunity for value addition and new farmer income.The project partners will aim to develop interventions to improve such internal and external processes, while putting data autonomy first and offering farmers a fair remuneration for the use of their data. The project is successful if all farmers are digitally included in the value chain and share data for both upstream and downstream partners of Verstegen, up until the end consumers, that can be monetized and directly distributed back to farmers.This two-year nutmeg project is the prelude to making all supply chains traceable to the last mile and product information transparent to consumers, within the coming five years. Specific objectives are to know all farmers by name and engage them through generating a new income stream that should help them towards earning enough for a living income. This is part of a long-term strategy to safeguard the supply of Indonesia’s iconic nutmeg spice, produced sustainably by and for future generations.

The embassy of the Netherlands in Maputo received 2 request for support of the DRR-Team. The request for DRR support in the city of Nacala, thas suffers from erosion and floods, is to analyse the existing municipal report and to advise on measures (projects) to prevent erosion and improve drainage and to advice on financing options for the projects. A roadmap for next steps to further develop projects and to arrange finance will be included.The request for the city of Pemba focuses on the risk of floods due to abundant rainwater, floods from the sea during cyclones and sanitation. The DRR-Team is requested to review the existing report of Gauff Engineering (2015) and to analyse the erosion and flood situation, the underlying causes and to advise on technical interventions, governance and financing options to reduce the negative impacts of erosion and floods. The sewage system, WWT options and the localisation of the ETAR will be reviewed and advise is requested on conclusions regarding construction, treatment options and localisation of the ETAR. A roadmap for next steps to proceed to feasibility study and finance of the project, is to be delivered.The expert should be able to combine and geo-reference data of all kind of sources and should have ample experience in finding and using open source data on a as detailed levels as possible.

The aim of the overall project is to contribute to the availability of improved, relevant and trustable spatial information available for the public and business on properties, infrastructures and environmental issues in Moldova. This is achieved by strengthening the Agency for Land Relations and Cadastre (ALRC) of Moldova and related institutions in a project of 22 months. This project provide additional co-financing to enable the input of Dutch expertise in this EU funded Twinning project.
Development and piloting of a data collection plan for the Ayeyarwady Delta

This project aims to support the Real Estate Cadastre Committee of the Republic of Armenia with the digitalisation of the cadastral archives in Armenia, through trainings, advice and study visits. The project is contributing to Armenia’s  economic development and the strengthening of the private sector, as digitalisation of cadastral archives will lead to  more transparency and better quality of land- and property documentation.

Infrastructure investment plans in the Manila Bay, Philippines are often made ad hoc and do not take the complete development needs of the area including fields like e.g. sanitation, water quality improvements and disaster risk reduction properly into account.  These limitations are addressed in the Manila Bay Sustainable Development Master Plan (MBSDMP)  that is being developed with Dutch expertise. Currently different donors and companies are as a result of the MBSDMP, preparing several follow-up projects as well as technical assistance projects in these fields in the Manila Bay. In this PSD Toolkit project a well-organized database and is prepared for these TA projects under development and for companies willing to invest in the Manila Bay. In a workshop these databases including explanations on how to use the data for ToR inputs for future projects will be disseminated to donors, companies and parties active in the Manila Bay.

The Pacific Tourism Data Initiative collects and reports tourism data through an International Visitor Survey (IVS) and  Business Confidence Index (BCI) to inform evidence-based tourism investment and decision making in the Pacific.

Kiribati is scheduled to undertake its Population and Housing Census in November 2020. The Census will form the baseline for future population-based social and economic policy. This Activity will provide funding to the Government of Kiribati to enable completion of this national exercise.

Oxfam Rwanda would like to seek Buffer Funds to implement a two tier project that links programme quality, monitoring, evaluation, learning and accountability with following key interventions: 1. Capacity building programme for partners and staff  - Training will be conducted for Oxfam Rwanda partners' and staff to orient them on Common Approach to MEL and Social Accountability (CAMSA). A Monitoring Evaluation and Learning (MEAL) capacity assessment for partners will also be conducted to identify gaps, followed by the development of a MEAL capacity building plan. The capacity building on systematic MEAL will be continuous to reinforce the skills and knowledge amongst partners to enable them to deliver effective programme with impact. The country programme will also establish a learning hub and a platform for convening and sharing as a part of influencing. 2. Using ICT4D in Data collection :Through Iformbuilder mobile platform  Technology (https://www.iformbuilder.com/contact -us/)  together with IPad devices, Oxfam Rwanda programme will fully deploy ICT4D technology in Data collection and later on in Reporting, form design will be done through Iformbuilder  and data will be hosted  and accessed at the Oxfam account  and IPad Mini 2 with 3G will be used to save money  and time spending in Data collection  and also Data quality will be  granted.

Ethical Trading Initiative (ETI) has been in existence since 1998, with particular focus on supply chains for the past 5 years. It is now planning a survey of workers in several countries to better understand what has changed for workers in these 5 years, either due to ETI's work in supporting members to work towards our Base Code standards or due to other drivers.    The overall purpose of the broad study will be to ascertain direct contribution to impacts by ETI and Oxfam and will also help us to gain a deeper understanding of the world of global supply chain workers and to assess our contribution to the changes taking place within it.   Morocco is one of three countries in which ETI will be involved in conducting such worker surveys. This study will be managed by Oxfam – Oxfam Great Britain and Oxfam Intermon. It will test the SenseMaker approach for this kind of study. It will seek to identify where progress seems to have been made in recent years although it is unlikely that a precise 5 year span can be explored due to the methodological limitations of not having a baseline and of historical recall of the workers.

General Objective: To obtain actionable information to propose public policy solutions using data analysis from digital technologies (i.e. Big Data). The results will contribute to deepen our understanding of social problems associated to different typesof inequality.
Specific objectives:
# To position Oxfam Mexico as an innovative partner who creates bridges between state-of-the-art researchon Big Data and data activism.
# To develop a pilot to promote inclusive public policies with a multidimensional understanding of inequality.
# To insert Oxfam Mexico in the national and international data science and data activism ecosystem.
Methodology: The project will use data from private providers such as Cuebiq, a firm that uses cellular data to map mobility patterns, to measure movements in the city, inspired by the model developed by the MIT Media Lab in their Atlas of Inequality. Additionally, an origin-destination matrix will be generated using metadata from mobile phones (Call Detail Records or CDRs). This is an innovative tool that will add new sources of information to the current data from the Mexico City government and other public institutions.
The results of thisproject will be used as inputs for Oxfam's urban inequality interventions in a timeline of projects developed until 2020.

LGBTQI organisations in Kenya, Tanzania and Uganda have limited opportunity to speak. When they do, it's vital they have the tools and resources they need to communicate effectively.Data4Change (D4C), with input from Voice Global, will select eight LGBTQI organisations from our existing and trusted partners in target countries to participate in DataWise. Trusted partners from other countries may be included as agreed by D4C and Voice.DataWise empowers grassroots organisations working at the intersection of LGBTQI, women’sand young people’s rights to use data, design, and storytelling to build and strengthen community,inspire action, and hold power toaccount. After participating in DataWise, organisations will: collect and use data to inform and implement innovative advocacy strategies; transfer newly acquired data skills to their own communities using D4C toolkits andresources; and communicate insights from original data and research online and offline to hyper-local, regional, and global audiences. The eight selected organisations will be split into two cohorts of four. Each cohort will complete a full set of activities thatfall under three streams: “collect”, “coach”, and “communicate”.Collect Eight LGBTQI organisations collaborate with D4C data coaches to identify relevant existing data (“datamaps”) and missing data (“data gaps”). Coaches work with each organisation to co-create an innovative, ethical and secure data collection strategy that generates original data about LGBTQI rights. Outputs Eight documentation packs, each including a data capacity assessment, a data maps and gaps profile, and a three-month data collection plan Eight new datasets collected and up to 40relevant open data sources Coach Up to 16 LGBTQI leaders (two per organisation)participate in D4C’s immersive and interactive three-month DataSkills Fellowship. They acquire a foundational understanding of the data workflow (collect, clean, understand,communicate) and apply these skills to create and publish a data project of theirown. They participate in virtual “link and learn”events to share knowledge with their cohorts and they lead in-person Data Skills Bootcamps to transfer knowledge to their communities. They confidently andactively use data insights to create and implementnew 12-month data advocacy strategies for their organisations and create up to two data-driven advocacy outputs each. Outputs 16 LGBTQI leaders participate in three-month fellowship 16 data-driven projects and training diaries Four“link and learn” events80 LGBTQI community members attend Data Skills Bootcamps Eight 12-month data advocacy strategies32 data-driven advocacy outputs Communicate LGBTQI organisations share data insights with diverse audiences from hyperlocal (e.g. their own communities, families) to global (e.g. diplomats, rapporteurs, funders). With D4C data, design and storytelling coaches, each organisation co-creates a series ofonline and offline communications as part of a data-driven‘dispatch’, and contributes to amulti-stakeholder, cross-regional and cross-theme data-driven advocacy campaign that speaks to a global audience. They participate in virtual meetings with international stakeholders, presenting original data on LGBTQI rights and reporting on their countries’ human rights records. Outputs Eight data-driven ‘dispatches’ Two data-driven advocacy campaigns Eight virtual meetings with international stakeholders.

This project aims to increase the data collection, analysis and visualisation capacities of Uganda, Tanzania and Kenya Human Rights Organisations (HRO) focused on empowering Lesbian-Gay-Bisexual-Transsexual-Intersex (LGBTI) people, women facing exploitation, abuse and/or violence, as well as indigenous groups and ethnic minorities.
The action comes from their research work in East Africa, where HRO in Tanzania and Uganda need training and collaborative innovation opportunities that support them to collect and present human rights documentation data. One of the questions this project aims to investigate is how to improve their offering of innovation and strategic guidance in design, development andsocial media for ongoing advocacy initiatives.
This project called Data4Change is inspired by a successful pilot project in Beirut that has proven responsive to regional and local HRO needs in the Middle East North Africa region. Inspired by the insightsof this model, it has been useful for human rights organisations to learn the fundamentals of research methodology, data gathering, data analysis, data storytelling and data advocacy.

From March 2015 to March 2018, with the support of EU and Oxfam, the Budget Transparency Coalition (BTAP) has successfully implemented the project "Promoting transparency and people#s participation in state budget management #. After 3 years of implementation, the project has achieved great results such as some information publicity policies have improved to some extends; Local authorities inHoa Binh and Quang Tri have applied the mechanisms for community involvement in monitoring, and community groups#members have become a positive factor in motivating people to participate in budget monitoring. From April to December 2018, Oxfam continues to support BTAP in replicating the project#s successful lessons to influence at larger-scale.

Regarding supporting people#s participation, until December 2018, 11 core groups have been established (9 groups in Quang Tri and 2 groups in Hoa Binh). New groups# capacity in budget monitoring, analysing, and public investment monitoring has been built through various activities such as trainings and experience sharings. In these activities, older groups have played an active role in guiding and supporting new groups in budget monitoring. With the mechanism in which older groups supporting the new ones, BTAP expects thecommunity monitoring model to be spread naturally and sustainably. In the coming time, BTAP will continue to support the spreading process through initiative funds, sharing experiences in budget monitoring by organizing sharing sessions between old and new groups, or sharing in periodical meeting with Quang Tri provincial Women#s Union, Farmers Association of Hoa Binh province, Hoa Binh provincial Fatherland Front and through social media.In addition, the "People monitoring budget" group will be established on Facebook to create a forum for all residents to approach, share experiences and concerns relating to budget monitoring. Via the open forum above, BTAP will promote learning sharing and technical support for people#s participation in budget monitoring.

Regarding governmental support to expand the space for people#s participationin in decision making and monitoring budget implementation, the authorities in Hoa Binh and Quang Tri provinces have developed mechanisms such as the Scoring tools to select public investment projects, Social audit tools to assess the quality of public investment projects, Policy consultations, Community consultation mechanism to manage development budget of commune. Moreover, the People's Councils at all levels in the project area have also improved the effectiveness of policy implementation monitoring. In addition, the opportunity for people to comment and the accountability of People's Committees at all levels have been enhanced through policy dialogues. In the periodfrom April to December 2018, a total of 21 initiatives (11 initiatives were implemented in new districts and new communes) relating to the evaluation of public investment projects, policy dialogues and analysis have been carried out in Hoa Binh and QuangTriprovince. In the 2019-2020 period, BTAP continues to support governments in Hoa Binh and Quang Tri to implement a number of key policy initiatives to create more evidences for central-level policy advocacy. Thus, BTAP will support Mai Chau district People's Council to apply Scoring public investment tools and assist People's Council of Quang Tri province  evaluate the collective economic program.

Regarding promoting social dialogues on budget management, under the revised 2015 State Budget Law, the Government and People's Committees at all levels must publicize their budget estimation before getting approval from the National Assembly or People's Councils. During the reviewing period by the National Assembly and People's Councils, BTAP promotes publicdiscussionand people#s comment on the budget estimation. "2019 State budget estimation from expert perspective" seminar was held in Hanoi on October 29, 2018 with a total of 54 direct participants and 25,800 online viewers. There are more than 5,000peopleparticipating in the discussion, learning about the 2019 State budget estimation via website ngansachvietnam.vn and the Vietnam Budget fanpage. Opinions of experts and people on the 2019 State budget estimation were summarized by BTAP and sent to NationalAssembly deputies, the Ministry of Finance, and the Finance and Budget Committee of the National Assembly. MOF#s representative proposed a meeting with BTAP toexplain the contents of  recommendations relating to the 2019 State Budget Estimation.

Regarding monitoring the implementation of budget transparency policy, BTAP has applied the POBI initiative to assess the level of compliance of provincial authorities and MOBI initiative to assess the level of publicity of central agencies for regulationsrelated to budget transparency. The results of the survey were used by the Ministry of Finance to implement numerous strong actions to promote budget disclosure under the 2015 Budget Law. However, the survey only focused on 3 aspects of publicity (i) availability; (ii) timeliness; (iii) the adequacy of the budget documents but have not yet evaluated the quality, usefulness and participation. Therefore, BTAP proposes that these two surveys needto be completed in terms of evaluation criteria and are carried out annually to create a reliable tool promoting information publicity at the local level.

In 2017 and 2018, Oxfam have also supported BTAP to implement a project improving the role of commune health centers to enhance the quality of health servicesforthe poor, women and ethnic minorities in Quang Tri. The project has piloted the result-based financing model (RBF model) at 6 health centers. Although having just been implemented, RBF model has made some initial impacts to improve service delivery qualityof health centers. RBF activities have facilitated community participation in quality assessment/ service delivery scoring of health centers. Based on this assessment, health centers# budget utilization is improved. However, RBF has just beenpiloted ina short period of time, the evidence and policy messages relating to the allocation of grassroots health budgets based on the operation results are stil unclear. Therefore, BTAP suggests that the implementation of RBF in Quang Trineed more time.

Budget isone of the most important content of economic and social management. If managed in a transparent manner, ensuring accountability and efficiency, budget expenditure plays an important role in poverty reduction, social and economic development. Therefore, BTAP will continue to promote transparency and efficiency in budget management with a comprehensive approach from policy improvement, policy implementation monitoring and community participation support. With the above analysis, BTAP proposes tocontinueimplementing the next phase of the project "Promoting transparency and the people#s participation in state budget management #Expanding period# with the aim of maintaining budget management initiatives, broadening the scope of their impact, andmovingtowardsadvocating institulization into policy solutions for more widespread adoption.

Inclusive Friends Association (IFA) is an NGO led by a woman with disability, committed to addressing barriers faced by persons with disability. They were one of the recipients of Voice 'NOW US AWARD' previously and have now applied for this sudden opportunity grant to address issues around data for people with disability (PWD). They identified this gap as one of the key challenges faced by PWD in accessing social services but more importantly in participating in election. The data collection will identify the PWDs in a particular community and also disaggregate them by type of disability. This will enable INEC officials who has the responsibility of organizing elections in Nigeria, to plan better for the participation of PWDs in each community.

The goal of the Data for Inclusionproject is to increase the participation of persons with disabilities (PWDs) in Nigeria#s political and electoral processes by collecting disaggregated data of PWDs and influencing the reduction of physical barriers and stigma that make it difficult for PWDs to participate in elections. The project would collect data of PWDs in 12 states (2 in each geographical zone) and influence INEC, Edo and Ondo state governments to use the data in providing ramps in polling units that are inaccessible to PWDs in these states. IFA andits partners, Network for the Advancement of Rights of Persons with Visible Disabilities (NAPVID) in Edo and the Ondo state Disabled Welfare Agency (ODWA) would recruit PWD leaders in the 266 local governments areas (LGAs) in the 12 states to manually collect these data from local communities and also set up a technological centre to electronically facilitate the collection of the PWD data from most of the urban centres. Massive media sensitization programs would also be conducted to create awareness on how PWDs can send their data into the database.

In the lead up to the governorship elections in both states, IFA and its partners would hold a PWD focused Live TV Manifesto debates for governorship candidates in Edo and Ondo states to provide opportunity for PWD leaders ask for inclusive policies from prospective governors. PWD leaders in all the local governments in both states would be trained on issue-basedapproaches to prepare them for the debates. IFA and its partners would also hold quarterly review meetings in four geographical locations and use lessons learnt in strengthening its strategy on the project. This project would be implemented within 11months period

Specific Objectives of the projectare:

1. Collect PWD disaggregated data and influence institutional reforms in INEC to promote inclusive elections.
2. Empower PWDs in Edo and Ondo state with tools for building active citizens engagements with state executives to foster PWD inclusivepolicies through manifesto debates.
3. Use data to influence the provision of ramps in inaccessible polling units in Edo and Ondo by state executives.
4. Produce an inclusive practice through documentation of outcomes that can be replicated in other parts of the world

The HSS is a methodology developed by PAX to better understand and leverage the experiences and perceptions of civilians living in conflict to shape protection policy and practice. With local partners we facilitate dialogues with communities and authorities around the survey findings and identify practical ways to improve the security situation. At the international level, the HSS is used to influence policy providing first-hand information about conflict-affected populations. The survey is continued over multiple years to track trends and work towards sustainable change. In South Sudan, we work in close collaboration with two respected local partners: the Assistance Mission for Africa and the Justice and Peace Commission-Catholic Diocese of Torit.

Through the Human Security Survey, PAX and its local partners use both data and dialogue to increase the understanding of how local communities in Iraq experience and are impacted by insecurity in order to inform better protection policies and practices. The survey is administered by local enumerators using smartphones. All members of the data collection teams are carefully selected and trained in the principles of conflict- and gender-sensitive research methods; in practices in random selection; in digital security; and in effective listening skills. The survey instrument itself was designed in consultation with the local partners, will be refined as necessary to be contextually relevant and appropriate based on feedback from enumerators and participating community members. The quantitative data will be validated through discussions with local and international experts, and supplemented with rich qualitative data generated through the community dialogue events. Findings will be shared with key stakeholders both in Iraq and internationally through presentations, media, and written reports, and are subsequently followed up by targeted advocacy efforts.PAX and its partners will undertake continuous reflection and periodic evaluation to verify the extent to which these activities contribute to more people-centered security interventions, and ultimately to the improved security of civilians in Iraq.
