Internal workgroup on Agriterra's strategy on ICT and cooperatives
Motivation
ICT and finance play a vital role in food productivity and income. During a visit to the 'Geodata for Inclusive Finance and Food' conference in February 2017 (by NpM, Netherlands Space Office and Rabobank Foundation) we saw many initiatives on Geodata and many suppliers of ICT solutions to agriculture. 
  
Most projects give partial solutions on one aspect of the agriculture production cycle (eg. soil analysis, weather information, plant disease analysis, financial analysis). They usually need a considerable of labour input for data collection and communication with end users. Time and again, they lack possibilities to bring the solution to scale, due to lacking profitability. 
All solutions for agriculture based on new technology encounter a central difficulty in identifying the unique farmer and his/her location. Additionally, the grid of the geodata is still not that advanced that small farmer plots can be located from space. Agriterra works through agricultural cooperatives and farmers organisations. Agriterra would like to know the state-of-the-art suppliers of solutions to agriculture, using ICT and/or geodata and specialized software, as they are in the market and cover together most aspect of the production cycle and crop chain. 
  
We think there are possibilities to bundle solutions as provided by service providers and supplying and off-taking companies in the chain, and chain partners themselves into a profitable business plan.
  
Agriterra is not yet familiar with the possibilities, but we see the urgency and need to start to work in this area as well, to improve the livelihood of the smallholder farmers. We would like to introduce these new ICT technologies via Agriterra to the cooperatives and farmer organisations who we work with. 
  
Which IC Technology suppliers can we work with? in order to reach all our farmers in the 14 focus countries of the current Agriterra programme. Therefore, we would like to get an insight in the the potential sources and providers of geodata, big data and agricultural applications, in order to know which suppliers are best suited to work with as Agriterra to reach our goals. 
  
https://agriterraindewolken.sh...

The Swedish Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) has applied to the Embassy for funding of SEK 9 million for three years (2021-2023) for the contribution Environmental Capacity Building on Data Use. The core of the contribution is capacity building on data management at the Kosovo Environmental Protection Agency (KEPA) with three thematic focus areas: air pollution, climate change and water management. Communication on environmental issues to both decision makers and the wider public is proposed to underpin the thematic areas and be a substantial part of the contribution.

There are four specific objectives of the contribution: 1) Strengthened communication; providing correct and comprehensive environmental data to decision makers and to the general public, 2) Improved environmental information systems; develop management and analysis of environmental data, 3) Capacity development for sustainable water management; support in implementing several of the plans already developed for better water management and 4) Strengthened implementation capacity for environmental quality improvement measures; using analytical tools such as cost benefit analysis and feasibility studies in an integrated manner when developing action plans, especially in the area of air quality and climate change.

The overall objective of the contribution is to strenghten organisational and individual capacity at KEPA to work in line with guidelines from the European Commission and that way support Kosovo towards EU accession.

SEPA will be the sole agreement partner and there are no other donors for the contribution.

Statistics Sweden and National Institute of Statistics (NIS) in Cambodia has applied to Sida for funding of SEK 18 800 000  to carry out the "Cooperation Project between the National Institute of Statistics in Cambodia and Statistics Sweden" in Cambodia during the period 2020-2022. 

The intervention aims at improving the quality of statistical production in Cambodia as well as the usage of this statistics by 1) improving the quality and usage of National Accounts; 2) improve the statistical capacity within NIS as well as the National Statistical System; 3) ensure a stable ICT infrastructure and ICT systems for managing, producing and disseminating data and Statistics; 4) increase NIS's capacity to disseminate key Statistics in a user-friendly way and increase statistical literacy among key users and; 5) strenthen internal coordination within NIS as well as the wider coordination mechanisms for coordination within the National Statistical System.

Statistics Sweden will implement the intervention together with the National Institute of Statistics (NIS) in Cambodia. The Department of Economic Policy within the Ministry of Economy and Finance is also a key stakeholder who will be a recipient of expertise from Statistics Sweden.

The intervention’s total budget is SEK 18 800 000.

In addition Sweden shall support implementation of the  2020  Action Plan for implementation of the DEI's Communication Strategy in the amount of 1.05 MSEK. 
Component 1.
The data base “MERSA” should primarily be the NIPAC Office’s internal tool of managing the information and processes related to IPA funds and it must assure management of these processes primarily within the NIPAC Office.  It should also assign rights to partner institutions for entering certain data, or for preparing surveys of certain topics and themes. Furthermore, within the same contribution, DEI/NIPAC will develop the Legal Harmonization Data Base (LHDB) system, to adequately support the recording, monitoring, tracking, analyzing and reporting on legal acts in BiH and their level of harmonization with the EU acquis. 
Component 2. 
Sweden's assistance to this Component relates to  implementation of the  2020  Action Plan for implementation of the DEI's Communication Strategy for Informing the Public on the Accession Process of BiH. All actions proposed are divided into 4 components : Events; Digital communications and video production;  Publishing and Regional cooperation. Envisaged budget for implemetation of this Component is 1,05 MSEK while duration of the intervention is 12 months.

Hence, total budget for the intervention ( both components ) is 5,05 million SEK over the period 2020-2021 (2020: 4,05MSEK; 2021: 1 MSEK)

Statistics Sweden has applied to Sida to initiate a second phase (2020 - 2022) of a statistical collaboration with the overall aim of strengthening the capacity of the statistical authorities in Somalia. Phase I ran between 2015 and 2019 and this second phase is now aiming at consolidating and developing the capacity and knowledge acquired by the participating Somali authorities in the first phase.

This will be done by continuing to support the Somali statistical authorities. The overall objective of the project is thus to:

Strengthen the statistical capacity in Somalia in order to facilitate decision-makers' awareness, understanding and confidence in statistical data.

The project's expected results are:

1) Improved quality in the production of social and economic statistics.
2) Improved and strengthened capacity among the statistical authorities in the statistical method.
3) Increased access to high quality statistics and data.
4) Improved and strengthened planning and organization of the statistical authorities.

This second phase is expected to strengthen the institutional and technical capacity of the Statistics Office of the Federal Government of Somalia (FGS) and of the Statistics Office of Puntland. Somaliland has been part of phase I of this effort and the ambition is to have them included again in this second phase.

With increasing changes in the climate and human interventions, sustainable management of land resources is becoming a major challenge, especially in developing countries where the economy relies heavily on agriculture and natural resources. Belowground organisms are an important component of biodiversity, contributing to the functioning and productivity of terrestrial ecosystems, yet they are often neglected in conservation planning and resource management. In this project, we aim to determine whether there is a link between belowground biodiversity and productivity based on a gradient of crop and forest productivity inferred from traditional knowledge. This will be achieved along with promoting research and capacity building regarding the role of belowground diversity for forest and crop productivity in W. Africa. We leverage ethnopedological knowledge in the region to infer productivity trend, soil types and land-use change history. Using these data as metadata and for selecting study sites, we will employ state-of-the-art methods to examine belowground diversity and mycorrhizal colonization rates in relation to productivity and land-use change history. This project represents major steps towards addressing the question of how belowground diversity can contribute to sustainable use of land resources and how we can leverage the rich traditional knowledge of the ecosystem in the region for this purpose.

Proxy-based climate reconstructions from Southern Africa are currently limited in both quality and quantity, and expanded data on past hydroclimate is central for better assessments of regional climate change. Paleo-data is also critical for the calibration of climate models, which outcomes may have direct impact on rural societies dependent on predictable rainfall for subsistence. With this proposal we aim to reconstruct Southern African hydroclimate variability, with emphasis on the nature and frequency of extreme rainfall anomalies, and associated ecosystem impacts. Geochemical tools will be applied on sedimentological sequences sampled from climate sensitive ecosystems in South Africa, Lesotho and Mozambique. More specifically, we will; 1) implement state-of-the-art compound specific isotope analysis (CSIA) and X-ray fluorescence scanning (XRF) for hydroclimate proxy reconstructions - a proxy-combination optimal for unambiguous and robust interpretative assessment, 2) focus on high-resolution data for identification of short-term extreme events and abrupt climate shifts, 3) provide tight chronological control for optimal inter-site comparison and identification of potential leads and lags within and between climate- and eco-systems, 4) run climate model simulations with a coupled earth system model. In parallel, biogenic methods will yield data on local aquatic- and regional vegetation dynamics, providing a coupling between ecosystem response and climate change.

The Embassy received from the government of Burkina Faso, a request for technical and financial support for the benefit of the statistics sector. To respond to this request, the Embassy facilitated exchanges between the National Institute of Statistics and Demography (INSD) of Burkina Faso and Statistics Sweden. These discussions resulted in the development and adoption of terms of reference for the formulation of a project to support. In reaction to these terms of reference, SCB submitted to the Embassy a proposal for a mission to formulate a cooperation project. The final objective of this mission is to produce a project document which will be formulated and developed jointly by INSD and SCB. 

This contribution, which is thus a preparatory phase, will be led by SCB. The aim is to finance the further development of a sustainable statistical system in Burkina Faso. Part of the budget will be used to procure local consultants to support SCB's experts.
The assignment will be carried out through review of existing documents, in-depth interviews, group discussions and workshops.

The assignment is scheduled to begin on January 1, 2021 and end no later than April 30, 2021.

The total budget for the intervention is SEK 1 million. About 380,000 SEK of the intervention budget will be at the disposal of the Embassy and used for procuring local consultants.

The contribution aims to promote transparency and inform public through the disclose of data on government spending, procurement, contracting, asset declaration, health public sector, state owned enterprises and other sectors with high risk of corruption, to instil the watchdog culture and encourage anti-corruption efforts.

A results objective of many of Sweden’s development cooperation strategies is to increase production and access to renewable energy. An important constraint in the quest to achieve a significant scale up of investments in distributed supply of renewable energy services is a lack of high quality, reliable and up-to-date data and information on rural and peri-urban parts of Africa and Asia.

This data is crucial for businesses and investors to make decisions about entering markets and tailor their offering to local conditions, and for governments and development stakeholders to design policy and plan action.

Data on customer willingness and ability to pay is particularly crucial (and particularly difficult to obtain), as clean energy technology sold on a pay-as-you-go basis requires a much more complex and long-term relationship between vendor and customer than, for example, selling candles would. Traditional financiers would never consider providing a loan to a customer with no bank account or credit rating, but off-grid energy service providers do not have a choice. This situation requires new ways of operating, which makes off-grid energy service providers risky in the eyes of investors.

The role of data in modern economies today can hardly be overstated. Rich data ecosystems in industrialised countries have fed astonishingly, and increasingly, sophisticated analytics. For over a decade, data analytics have been the lifeblood of investment decisions, product testing and launches, market entries and expansions, and other processes in nearly every sector of modern economies. In 2020, an absence of data translates to a surfeit of risk, and ultimately inertia.

Beyond the private sector, data is also underutilised by developing country governments and development agencies in planning policies and interventions, leading to inefficient planning, sub-optimal decision-making, and inadequate outcomes. OECD country governments use vast amounts of data for purposes ranging from optimising bus routes to predicting flu epidemics. 

The effects of any intervention, whether it is a change in traffic light patterns or a new approach to public information campaigns on flu shots, can be measured and responded to in real time. Developing country governments tend to miss out on these opportunities due to both a lack of reliable data and a lack of funding for programmes and systems to collect, manage and analyse data.

Africa’s data ecosystem is perhaps the world’s most underdeveloped. As the Data for African Development Working Group pointed out in its 2014 Final Report, “nowhere in the world is the need for better data more urgent than in Africa, where data quality is low and improvements are sluggish, despite investments from country, regional, and international institutions to improve statistical systems and build capacity.” 

Through the Beyond the Grid Fund for Zambia contribution funded by the Swedish Embassy in Lusaka, the implementing partner Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Partnership (REEEP) and Sweden have established a first version of a data platform that provides real-time, unique and detailed data on energy use and financial transactions involving more than 150,000 customers living beyond the reach of the national electricity grid - the system is called Energy Data on Off-grid Energy Networks System (Edison). The EDISON software platform handles automated data collection, storage, access, analysis and visualization to verify the installation and use of solar systems under BGFZ's performance-based financing mechanism. Analyses based on EDISON also feed into the dialogue platform established by the Ministry of Energy in Zambia that brings together Zambian authorities, donors, development banks and energy services companies in Zambia.

An expansion of the results-based financing mechanism tested in Zambia is now applied in the new contribution Beyond the Grid Fund for Africa, where the Nordic Environment Financing Corporation is the agreement partner. This will provide the opportunity to collect similar data in Burkina Faso, Liberia and Mozambique reaching an additional 1 to 3 million customers. 

At the same time, a number of additional public and private stakeholders with activities linked to the "off-grid" sector have shown great interest in collaborating around Edison in collecting, processing, storing, analyzing and visualizing data in the context of other off-grid programs and financing mechanisms and thereby increase the amount of data available for analysis. 

In November 2019, the Swedish Embassy in Nairobi hosted a roundtable to explore, together with a number of stakeholders, opportunities for collaboration between actors who collect and use big data for development purposes and interest in further developing and making EDISON available as a tool for more stakeholders to use and collaborate around.

REEEP has subsequently submitted an application amounting to 5 MSEK for support, in collaboration with, among others, the Africa Mini-Grids Develompent Association (AMDA), the Global Off Grid Lighting Association (GOGLA), the International Energy Agency (IEA), the Sustainable Energy for All, the International Renewable Energy Agency (IRENA) and the Energy Sector Managment Assisance Program at the World Bank (ESMAP), The Global Energy Data Commons (GEDC), to further develop and make EDISON available to a wider group of stakeholders.

REEEP has applied to Sida for funding of 476 316 EUR to carry out the "Edison II - Building and integrated energy data ecosystem for Africa" during the period 2020-2021. 

The intervention aims at further develop the data collection, storage and analysis platform, EDISON, to make it available for use by a broader range of actors by 1) harmonising data and KPIs of key stakeholders for household solar energy systems and mini-grid solutions for inclusion in specifications of EDISON II and development of a proof-of-concept investment instrument suitable for emerging economies with tranched risk tiers and associated returns; 2) Development, launch and testing of EDISON II energy monitoring and analytics platform and 3) Discussion and documentation of Global Energy Data Commons infrastructure; proposal-writing and fundraising for Energy Data Roadmap for Africa (incl. side-event at SEforAll Forum 2020); facilitation of standardized dataset development for SDG7 tracking.

REEEP will lead the implement the contribution but also engage primary partners AMDA, GOGLA and IEA to participate in working sessions on the KPI harmonisation. It is also anticipated that SNV will be engaged around how to use EDISON in the DFID funded BRIHLO programme in Mozambique. 

The intervention’s total budget is 476 316 EUR, out of which the organisation’s own funding is approximately 15 000 EUR. IEA is expected to cover their own costs of participating in the intervention.

Statistics Sweden, SCB, applies for support for full cost coverage in phase 1B (preparation and presentation of twinning proposals) within the framework of the EU twinning project "Support the strengthening of official statistics in order to better answer the needs of the users and building on exchanges and transfers with/from the EU statistical system", which will take place in Palestine. EU reference: PS 18 ENI ST 01 19 R. In this project, Statistics Sweden will be a junior partner in a consortium with the German Federal Ministry for Economic Affairs and Energy (BMWI). The partner's beneficiary administration involved in the twinning project is the Palestinian Central Bureau of Statistics - PCBS.

The Partnership in Statistics for Development in the 21st Century (PARIS21) is a global partnership of national, regional and international statisticians, development professionals and policy makers seeking to improve evidence-based decision making mainly in low-income developing countries. The main accent of PARIS21’s activities is to stimulate the dialogue between data producers and users and act as a knowledge hub in the field of statistical capacity building.

VDC intends to continue providing evidentiary material to SCM’s litigation program, the IIIM, and other international partners engaged in litigation. This collaboration will involve designing a joint strategy to select the cases that would shed light on the most serious violations taking place in Syria, while successfully leading to the conviction of perpetrators. In order to do so, VDC intends to identify relevant information it can provide legal actors with, and strategically incorporate such considerations into its documentation methodology and tools. As part of its new database, VDC intends to develop a War Criminals Observatory, which would serve as a reliable database of alleged perpetrators of war crimes and crimes against humanity in Syria, as well as a Terrorists’ Observatories listing documented potential perpetrators of terrorist acts and/or organisations who took part in relevant activities in Syria. Both observatories appear to be essential tools to support strategic litigation efforts. VDC has already started working on this initiative and a significant number of suspects were identified, documented, and verified. VDC also intends to identify and monitor locations of interest to them and to SCM’s litigation program, such as prisons, courts, or mass graves.

Through the development of a new documentation methodology, VDC intends to establish strong foundations to enable the conduct of in-depth qualitative and quantitative studies addressing patterns of violations that can serve to support and inform accountability efforts. This work aims to highlight the interconnected nature of legal, political and social issues and their influence on conflict and post-conflict dynamics so they can be better addressed as part of a transitional justice process. To do so, VDC will continue providing evidentiary material to relevant actors and keep producing monthly reports. Once the new methodology and tools are adopted, VDC intends to set up a team specialised in legal research and studies to support insightful discussions around current legal concerns where potential violations could emerge. VDC seeks to start a collaboration with a Human Rights Clinic to produce detailed evidence-based studies of emerging legal issues related to the Syrian conflict and engage with other civil society actors to identify emerging types of violations which require more attention. VDC intends to develop a specialised methodology to monitor and document violations key to a meaningful transitional process and prioritise the issue of the “safe return of refugees” in its engagement strategy by developing specific monitoring and documentation mechanisms to provide feedback on “voluntary return” cases. VDC intends to ensure clear conditions for a safe return are established and fully understood. A flawed implementation of safe return would result in the foreseeable reoccurrence of escape and asylum seeking.

Down time of pumps is a big issue. Access in fragile situations also. This programme provides further learning on using sensors at pumps to collect information on their status, need for maintenance and repair and so reduction of down time. It will also develop case studies on the systems to support repairs and maintenance. It will lastly involve other WASH partners to provide opportunities for scaling.

The D4D program is designed to improve data and information ecosystems at the provincial and local spheres for evidence-based decision-making that addresses local development challenges. It will work to achieve the following outcomes:

(1) Improved coordination among federal, provincial and local government and non-government actors in data and statistics production. 
(2) Provincial and local governments use evidence-based, participatory decision-making processes. 
(3) Better data and analysis available to support the use of evidence in decision making by provincial and local governments

The evaluation will focus on the following areas of inquiry: 
•	Assess the achievement of the overall impact and outcome targets and whether or not the activities and outputs of the GODAN initiative (GODAN Secretariat and GODAN Action) have enhanced accountability and transparency, improved service delivery, innovation and economic growth and whether or not there have been any unintended outcomes;
•	Assess the programme theory of change (ToC) to see if the logic, supporting evidence and assumptions held up against implementation experience? Is there any evidence which challenges the programme design or rationale?  
•	Consider whether or not the programme has had a beneficial impact on women in terms of providing a greater voice in decision making; greater choice in opportunities to benefit from paid work and to have sufficient income; and greater control over their income, productive assets and other resources.
•	To assess the overall sustainability of the programme.

Programme for 4 sub projects:
1. Digital Transformation of the IFRC Network
2. Setting up a Rapid prototyping service for the IFRC Network
3. Setting up Cash IM support service and products for National Societies and their partners
4. Content creation for data literacy in the IFRC Network and contribute to closing the digital divide
5. IFRCs DT strategy implementation through (cash) contribution
6. Data and Digital Support to NS (extension of the global covid project, similar to the MENA Data & Digital Support).

One of the key activities in the new IFRC Digital Strategy is to close the digital divide in the network, and to build the data literacy of all national societies. Together with the IFRC Intervention team we want to develop a training curriculum that helps national societies to move along the levels of maturity in the IFRC Digital Maturity model (levels 1-5).

The support provided is flexible and demand driven. It also follows a human centered process, ensuring that client needs and the local context drive the definition of NLRC's support. The identified needs must be realistic in scope, must be within the ability of the NLRC to answer and finally, there must be a clear commitment from the recipient NS to engage proactively with NLRC throughout the project. The countries that will ultimately receive support through this project have not yet been determined but are expected to primarily be in the MENA (Middle East and Northern Africa) regions. Based on the knowledge collected and the changing dynamic of the pandemic, we anticipate that recipient national societies will request data and digital support in the following (generic) areas:
1.	Continuation of crucial data & digital support for NS for emergency support products
2.	Support NS data and digital support for Covid vaccination campaign. 
3.	Compounding disasters:  disaster response complicated by to the Covid pandemic
4.	Cash IM support

"The United Nations Foundation serves as the institutional host of the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development Data, which brings together government, private-sector, civil society, and international institutions to harness new and traditional sources of data to better understand and address development challenges. This grant will support the implementation of the partnership’s strategic plan with the following goals: (a) the scaling of new technologies, data sources, and methods, building on existing systems to improve government decision making; (b) fostering a global movement of political, business, and civil society leaders to promote responsible data use by governments and public trust in this use; and (c) bringing to scale the use of timely and robust data for Sustainable Development Goals monitoring. This grant supports the Evidence-Informed Policymaking strategy goal that governments in East and West Africa make better use of data to improve decision making and outcomes for people. (Strategy: Evidence-Informed Policymaking)"
"for support of the Sustainable Development Solutions Network's thematic network on data"

"The United Nations Foundation serves as the institutional host of the recently established Global Partnership for Sustainable Development Data. The Global Partnership brings together governments, private sector, civil society, and international institutions to harness new and traditional sources of data to better understand and address development challenges. This grant provides programmatic and operational support for the Global Partnership, with an emphasis on the strategy, governance, and operational activities required during the critical start-up phase to establish strong leadership, effective decision making, and clear actions toward the ultimate goal of filling development data gaps and making data more open, accessible, and usable by decision makers and citizens."

"This grant will support UNICEF’s Data Must Speak program that will improve global knowledge about what works and where (or not) in the development and use of data-driven school profiles by local education officials, school personnel, and parents to make performance gaps more visible and identify specific local actions for better learning. UNICEF will support data improvement, development of user-friendly school monitoring tools and related training modules for school personnel and community members, and evaluation of the effectiveness of these social accountability tools in expanding parent participation and accountability in education service delivery in up to 10 countries."

"This grant will support the WORLD Policy Analysis Center to improve the quantity and quality of comparative policy data on laws and policies affecting women’s economic empowerment, equality, and population health, establishing a baseline for the sustainable development goal related to gender equality. The data, analyses of policies and outcomes, and rich infographics will be featured on WORLD’s user-friendly Web platform to engage and inform its users—government leaders, citizens, civil society, and researchers around the world."

"Data2X’s work is intended to improve the availability, quality, and use of gender data for decision making, as a part of the Sustainable Development Goals framework and beyond. This grant supports Data2X’s continued work to advocate for greater attention to and investment in gender data, and to facilitate technical partnerships between gender experts and major producers of social and economic data. With this grant, Data2X will increase its advocacy capacity by creating a more robust communications and policy engagement function. In addition, it will expand its capacity as a coordinating body and platform for gender data partnerships, ranging from improved civil registration and vital statistics to better measurement of work and labor force participation. "

"The Open Knowledge Foundation promotes open-source technologies and government open-data portals, and encourages stakeholders to use government data to increase the ability of citizens to make informed demands on government. This grant will support the Global Open Data Index to enable civil society organizations that use open data to improve community monitoring, advocacy, and journalism. Support will also be provided to strengthen the global network of Open Knowledge Communities."

Under this outcome ECA RO will support the production of quality, comparable and regular gender statistics to address national data gaps and meet policy and reporting commitments under the SDGs, CEDAW and the Beijing Platform for Action. Data gaps will vary between countries, but based on an assessment of data in the United Nations Minimum Set of Gender Indicators database, regional priorities include production of data on violence against women and girls, unpaid care work, gender gaps in access to decent work and pay, participation in public life and decision-making, and access to and use of information and communication technologies (as found in the regional assessment of gender statistics capacity).

Under this outcome ECA RO will support countries to make gender statistics accessible to all users, including governments, civil society, academia and the private sector. It will provide advocacy materials to encourage increased data sharing, dissemination of data and microdata and assist COs and PPs to facilitate data flows to regional and global SDG-related databases. It will develop the capacity of national statistical systems to communicate gender statistics through better understanding user needs and development of methods such as infographics, data visualization, and narrative. It will also support gender analysis of data to inform research, advocacy, policies and programmes and promote accountability.

This output will be implemented in partnership with CAPMAS, NCW, Economic Research Forum and civil society organizations.

In September 2018, the Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said that
the rate of sustainable development is too slow and that businesses need to
play a major role in ensuring that it speeded up. Paragraph 67 of the 2030 Agenda
and the Paragraph 133 of the New Urban Agenda both call for businesses to apply
their creativity and innovation to solve sustainable development challenges.
Sustainable Development Goal 17 encourages effective public-private
partnerships and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda contains commitments at the
highest political level to: “… develop policies and, where appropriate,
strengthen regulatory frameworks to better align private sector incentives with
public goals, including incentivizing the private sector to adopt sustainable
practices, and foster long-term quality investment.”

The 2017 Report of the High-Level Independent Panel to Assess and
Enhance the Effectiveness of UN-Habitat recognizes that most of the current
investment in urban areas comes from the private sector and corporate interests
and that the UN system must ensure that both public and private investment is
subject to democratic oversight, protects the commons and respects human
rights, and that it is aligned with the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development
and the Sustainable Development Goals. Since the private sector plays such a
large role in urban development, often with negative consequences, especially
for excluded groups, the Panel recommends that UN-Habitat explore ways to
encourage private sector actors to look at the unintended negative impacts of
their investments and find ways to mitigate them. 

UN-Habitat’s Strategic Plan 2020-2023 calls for a rethink regarding
engagement with the private sector to leverage investments in sustainable
urbanization and to promote more appropriate models of development.
Particularly within Outcome 1.3 - Effective settlements growth and regeneration,
and Outcome 2.3 - Frontier technologies and innovation, the Plan considers it
important that UN-Habitat strengthen its engagement with the private sector,
including ICT companies. 

This project, then, provides a significant opportunity to work with a
global business that is committed to aligning its business objectives with the
Sustainable Development Goals, and specifically the Datacenters Community
Development team which sees the sustainability of datacenter communities as a
key element of its core business. In Microsoft’s own words ‘In over 10 years of
building and managing our cloud infrastructure, we have come to understand that
proactive urban planning is also a critical component to the long-term
viability, growth, and social contribution of datacenters as social,
environmental and economic assets to their host communities versus burdens on
them.’ 

Microsoft’s has three datacenter community development objectives:


 Building community partnerships that deliver economic, social,
     liveability and environmental benefits
 Improving the quality of conversations between community
     leaders, organizations, and Microsoft
 Developing a strong,
     technically-skilled, and diverse local workforce


The purpose of the project is to develop an urban planning model
that can help Microsoft achieve these three objectives and make its datacenters
more integrated with the local communities which are hosting them. UN-Habitat
will use its 40+ years of experience of public participation, urban planning,
governance and research to support these objectives. 

Beyond Microsoft UN-Habitat will develop standards, guides and approaches that improve the sustainability of the
industry as a whole, while retaining the economic benefits that come with
datacenter development: the average U.S. large datacenter generates $7.8
million in annual wages and $77.7 million in construction phase wages (2016, US
Chamber of Commerce).

In 2017 there were an estimated 8.6 million datacenters across the
world (International Data Corporation), emitting about 2% of global greenhouse
gas emissions (UNFCCC, 2016) and accounting for 17% of the ICT sector’s carbon
footprint (Colocation America, 2018). With global IP traffic worldwide expected
to treble between 2017 and 2022, datacenter development will keep growing and
expand globally. With the industry’s growth, so will its waste and particularly
e-waste. Datacenter servers have to be replaced every 3-5 years and disposed
electronics worldwide already account for 2% of solid waste and 70% of toxic
waste (World Economic Forum, 2019). In this context, beyond Microsoft there is
a great opportunity for UN-Habitat to develop standards, guides and approaches
that improve the sustainability of the whole industry.

The
Colombo Metropolitan Region (CMR )is facing growing traffic
congestion. At present, the railway system carries about 13% of
passenger transport within the CMR while in addition long distance
trains and commuter trains are also operational in the CMR. Thus the
government aims to increase the share of railway in the overall
passenger and freight traffic substantially by improving
and modernizing the Sri Lankan railway network in the CMR, which
covers four heavily congested major passenger corridors, namely Main
Line, Coastal Line, Kelani Valley Line and Puttlam Line.
In
view of the above situation and the need to develop of four major
corridors, The Ministry of Transport and Civil Aviation (MoTCA)
and Sri Lanka Railways (SLR) are preparing the necessary projects to
be considered for financing by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) under
the Colombo Suburban Railway Project (CSRP)The Kelani Valley line has
been selected as a priority Project among the other lines.

Science-informed policies for reduced vulnerability to ocean hazards, for the global conservation and sustainable use of oceans, seas and marine resources, and increased resilience and adaptation to climate change, developed and implemented by Member States, requires reliable data and information products and services that are directly usable by predictive models, adaptive strategies and other strategies that will assist the global society with building increased resilience to climate change and other ocean and climate related challenges. IODE and its OBIS will continue developing and disseminating the relevant products and services.

Science-informed policies for reduced vulnerability to ocean hazards, for the global conservation and sustainable use of oceans, seas and marine resources, and increased resilience and adaptation to climate change require reliable quality-controlled data and information as well as long-term time series of ocean observations. The IODE programme has, since 1961, established a global network of oceanographic data centres and information centres that manage, share and disseminate data, information, products and services.

The project responds to the need for comprehensive, disaggregated, and reliable EiE data that can inform authorities and their partners towards better preparing, responding and recovering from the impacts of emergencies, thus building system resilience. The project specifically contributes to strengthening and promoting institutional information systems as an effective tool for coordinated education planning, response and delivery in times of crisis in two pilot countries. The project builds on the first phases of the initiative (FIT) n°8458.

The project will strengthen the resilience of education systems by ensuring improved management and use of data and information in Chad, Ethiopia, Palestine, South Sudan, Syria and Uganda. In particular, the project will strengthen Education Management Information Systems (EMIS) and support national capacities. It will allow national authorities and Education in Emergencies (EiE) actors to jointly assess educational needs and provide proper preparedness and response plans. As such, the proposed project will contribute to bridging the humanitarian-development divide. This form pertains to phase 1 & 2: case studies and conference.

UNESCO Tehran, with the support of UNESCO Bangkok, will build on the completed activities of the 39 C/5 by continuing to provide technical support in advancement of EMIS and ICT in education. UNESCO Tehran, in collaboration with UNESCO Bangkok, will conduct follow-up activities to build national capacities in strengthening EMIS. In addition, in line with the expressed needs and priorities of Iran and Turkmenistan, support will be provided to both Member States in the strengthening of ICT in ED policies.

UNESCO recognizes that fostering universal access to information and knowledge is key to building peace, sustainable development and intercultural dialogue. It is essential to maintain, increase and diffuse inclusive and open knowledge through international cooperation. This activity aims to contribute to the promotion of open and inclusive solutions through the development of policy frameworks and institutional capacity-building activities in promoting open solutions. Implemented through various cooperation and collaboration modalities, these activities will contribute to the creation of intercultural dialogue in knowledge societies.

This project's overall aim is to create policy and action relevant data to improve the advice and support for Member States to mobilize dialogue effectively for increased intercultural understanding in order to prevent and resolve conflicts and sustain peace. Through the creation of a comprehensive, global data set, the initiative will contribute to identifying: a) the drivers of effective dialogue; b) the relative strength of the different dimensions of the enabling environment for dialogue; c) the types of intervention needed to mobilize dialogue more effectively in different contexts. This second phase shall seek to collect, analyse and present the data, as well as creating impactful operational responses to it through a comprehensive Dialogue Support Facility.

EASTECO in collaboration with key stakeholders including UNESCO developed the EAC Regional STI Policy for adoption by Member States. However, the lack of reliable up-to-date data and indicators on the current status of STI at the country-level may hamper the realisation of the policy's objectives and expected outcomes. The establishment of national and regional STI baselines that enable the monitoring of STI indicators and the support for learning and policy decisions at multiple scales is the mainstream opportunity. UNESCO's GO-SPIN methodology offers the platform to address these gaps. In collaboration with multiple stakeholders, this project will develop a comprehensive regional STI database for evidenced-based STI policy decisions in the EAC.

With reference to the experience and necessity for the creation of a database for the International Coordination Committee for the Safeguarding and the Development of the Archaeological Site of Angkor (ICC-Angkor), it is very important to have a similar system for the World Heritage Site of Preah Vihear. The digital database is imperative and an essential tool for the management of the site where different entities (national and international) in close cooperation with the National Authority for Preah Vihear (NAPV) are implementing projects related to archaeology, conservation, restoration and tourism in relation to the ICC.

This project will build an online data entry and editing tool that will make it easier to publish small number observations to OBIS, allowing individual researchers to report important observations from under-represented areas and time periods and under-reported species.

Earlier this year the Permanent mission of the Russian Federation sent a Note Verbal to UNIDO expressing its intention to renounce the appropriation of their share of unutilized balances for 2017 and allocate the funds to support the new strategic priority of UNIDO – “Strengthening knowledge and institutions”. Later in a meeting of the Director of PRS with the representative of Russian PM it was agreed that the resources could be utilized in statistical and analytical activities of PRS given the new mandate of the Organization in this area. Subsequently, the Permanent mission recommended three statistical and academic institutions to be included in project activities.

The Programme for Country Partnership (PCP) for Cambodia will support the Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC) in the implementation of its national Industrial Development Policy (IDP) and more general in the implementation of its national strategy for inclusive and sustainable growth and sustainable development (Agenda 2030) with the dimensions of social, economic and environmental sustainability.

The country faces a lack of timely and internationally comparable statistical data to facilitate evidence-based policy decisions, and to monitor the contribution of development interventions by local government and private sector as well as international development partners and programmes, including the PCP to the achievement of their national development goals, mainly the IDP and towards SDG targets.

The project aims at facilitating to establish a framework for key and relevant statistics and indicators that would serve informed policy decision making and can monitor the impact of development efforts and in particular the PCP and the IDP in priority to SDG Goal 9, and other SDGs including other areas related to poverty reduction, industrialization and economic development, environmental protection, and development sustainability. More specifically on topics including employment, skills, income, water, energy, manufacturing, services (like tourism), responsible production and wastes, climate change mitigation, selected value chains like fisheries and other agro-value chains, industrial diversification, access to finance and IT services, and gender empowerment.

Through its activities, outputs and outcomes, this UNIDO project will address the need for coherent evidence-based measures for guiding policy prescriptions in the elaboration and implementation of Science, Technology and Innovation within the industrial development of the Republic of Seychelles.

The use of Science, Technology and Innovation as a tool and interconnectivity between the actors of the system of innovation are crucial to the preparedness for the 4th industrial revolution and successful adoption of its associated technologies.

This project has been elaborated based on a preparatory assistance mission in September 2019, country level dialogue, as well as the analysis of policy documents of the Government of the Republic of Seychelles. The aforementioned highlight the need for mapping and measuring the Seychelles National System of Innovation (SeNSI). It is also in line with UNIDO’s mandate which highlights the role of science, technology and innovation in fostering Inclusive and Sustainable Industrial Development (ISID).

The overall objective of the Project is to assist DST in developing an analytical framework for measuring firm-level innovation and the national system of innovation (NSI) by collecting data from firms and NSI actors, as a follow up of the first Indian innovation survey conducted by DST in 2011

The project marks the second phase of Regional project (SAP 120443) which was successfully completed in 2019.  In this phase, the project will continue to assist the recipient countries to improve the quality of industrial statistics that are relevant in the context of the emerging demands of data for SDG indicators, economic integration of countries to regional and global market and promotion of Industry 4.0, with special focus on productivity, digital economy and women’s empowerment.

In continuation of the technical work commenced by the phase, this project will further emphasize the implementation of UN recommendations related to general industrial statistics, index numbers of industrial production and business dynamics and entrepreneurship and statistics of small industrial enterprises.
