Update or develop agricultural statistics methodologies, develop capacities based on those methodologies and design national sustainable agricultural statistical systems to the benefit of 10 African countries (2nd phase of the Pan-African Statistics Programme (PAS-II) in the field of agricultural statistics and Phase 2 of the Global Strategy Programme, part of an umbrella programme in FAO with MTF/GLO/431/BMG).

Update or develop agricultural statistics methodologies, develop capacities based on those methodologies and design national sustainable agricultural statistical systems to the benefit of 15 countries (Phase 2 of the Global Strategy Programme, part of an umbrella programme with GCP/GLO/472/EC)
To improve evidence-based decision making at national level with the aim of ending hunger, achieving food security and promoting sustainable agriculture and rural development

To provide technical support to PBS for implementation of IAC by providing sufficient knowledge of new cost-effective technologies and international methodologies to implement the Agriculture Census 2021 in Pakistan.
To prepare Food Balance Sheets that show the trends in the overall national food supply
To establish a flow of reliable and timely data and information on agriculture to link national supply of agricultural products to the demand of local and international markets.

To provide data for a better understanding of the current state of agriculture and the structural changes that have occurred in recent years.
To update the sampling frames for the agricultural surveys that were also identified as priorities in the SPARS.
To support the preparations for the agricultural census 2022 in order to ensure it is methodologically sound and in line with FAO recommendations for the Programme for the World Census of Agriculture 2020 (WCA 2020)
To develop the census design, sample design of households, develop a detailed workplan and budget for the NACA
to be provided

Strengthening the capacity of food security and nutrition statisticians and analysts in 20 countries over a two-year period, to collect, analyze and interpret data to derive food security indicators according to internationally agreed standards. This will enable national institutions to generate data on SDG indicators 2.1.1 (Prevalence of Undernourishment) and 2.1.2 (Prevalence of moderate or severe Food Insecurity based on the Food Insecurity Experience Scale). The Project also supports FIES in-countries data collection.

To make reliable data available for gender-sensitive planning and budgeting and to ensure that equal opportunities enable women to benefit fully from national and regional agricultural investment and growth

To enable select states of India to implement and monitor additional SDG indicators under FAO custodianship and produce a how-to guide for other states in the country and other custodian agencies to understand how to undertake a similar innovative approach in supporting states to compile and publish SDG indicators.

To review the ongoing efforts of MoALD and technically assist to establish and make functional the NIASS by fulfilling the national agriculture data requirements and maintain the global standards.
To provide analytic support, drafting reports and capacity development of the SDG indicators analysis.
To increase the availability of accurate, timely, up-to-date and comparable gender statistics at the national, regional and international levels in Africa.

Company reporting on the 2030 Agenda is a complex issue that requires addressing a number of challenges, which may be grouped in two levels. There are issues related to the harmonization and consistency of financial information with sustainability reporting in general, and further issues with regard to aligning sustainability reporting with the SDGs monitoring framework and its indicators. However, many countries lack the institutional and technical capacity to adapt their corporate reporting environments to the new demands spurred by the 2030 Agenda and effectively assess the private sector contribution towards attaining the SDGs.

In this context, the project's goals are to:
- Develop and implement a mechanism to coordinate efforts among different national authorities in establishing a sustainability reporting framework.
- Help companies prepare and publish useful sustainability reports within that framework.
- Support Governments in the collection of comparable and reliable information on companies' contribution towards the SDG implementation aligned with the global framework of SDG indicators.

At the heart of this mechanism is the integration of financial and non-financial information as part of companies’ reporting cycles.

The project will improve quality and facilitate international comparability of sustainability reporting, as well as enable multiple authorities within Governments to articulate, collaborate, and better assess the private sector contribution towards attaining the SDGs. Ultimately, the project will enhance the SDG monitoring mechanism.

The project is a joint effort of UNCTAD, ECA and ECE to develop a coherent approach to measuring the impact of trade on gender equality and analysing the related impacts of COVID-19 using official statistics and building on the existing statistical data and capacity of countries.

The expected result will be an enhanced capacity of national statistical authorities to collate and disseminate data and statistics for policy makers for more gender-responsive trade policy and to analyse the gendered impacts of COVID-19 transferred via trade.

In the longer term, the project will enable a more coherent review of progress towards inclusive trade policy and equitable economic development as part of the 2030 Agenda.

The project aims at developing the existing statistical data on employment, wages and salaries, as well as turnover, productivity and profitability of businesses from the gender perspective. These data also enable the assessment of the effects of COVID-19 through trade, including by different types of businesses, i.e. SMEs, and by gender. The project will advance the use of evidence as a basis of gender-responsive trade policy and in support of the economic and social recovery from COVID-19.

This project, implemented by UNCTAD and UNECA in collaboration with UNODC, will focus on developing a statistical methodology to estimate IFFs with an aim to:

- Gain knowledge on the size of IFFs and their origins.
- Provide evidence for a targeted and effective policy response. 
- Improve the participating countries' capacity to measure IFFs over time, and monitor the impact of policies put in place to reduce these flows. 

The statistical methodology and the insights from its pilot testing in nine African countries will be published as part of the project. The pilot testing will provide feedback to the development of a globally-agreed methodology to measure IFFs and the related SDG indicator 16.4.1, for which UNCTAD and UNODC are custodian agencies.

The KSTA will support the development of economic data systems and knowledge solutions to facilitate policy analysis, formulation, and monitoring. It will employ multi-sourced data, advanced statistical methods, and modern training to strengthen the NSSs’ capacity in four specific areas: national economic accounts, SBRs, data innovation, and knowledge sharing and dissemination to provide timely and high-quality statistics to illuminate policy and produce reliable indicators to monitor progress on SDGs.

The TA project will focus on innovative approaches to producing key socioeconomic and SDG-relevant statistics in two domains: (i) data collection, management, and dissemination; and (ii) knowledge sharing on innovations in statistics.

PNG has a centralized statistical system with the National Statistics Office (NSO) under the Ministry of National Planning and Management. NSO is responsible for the collection, compilation and dissemination of all social and economic statistics. Other departments in the Central Government have very few personnel with the knowledge of statistics. Situation of statistical functionaries in other department is no different. There is lack of allocation of resources for statistical activities in the departments other than NSO. NSO does not have any unit or staff to take agriculture statistics related activities. The statistics system in PNG suffers from both lack of resources both manpower and training to personnel to carry out effective work of agriculture data collection. An agriculture census has not been conducted in PNG for more than 40 years. This lack of baseline agricultural statistics poses a severe challenge for the Government to monitor and evaluate the impacts of agricultural projects and national development indicators in the agricultural and rural development sector. It also compromises the ability of the Government to monitor progress against relevant Sustainable Development Goals. FAO, in partnership with the World Bank, the United Nations Statistical Commission, and in in consultation with national institutions developed the Global Strategy to Improve Agricultural and Rural Statistics. The IdCA preparation work under the Global Strategy project for PNG was undertaken in two phases. Based on the work in the two missions, an IdCA report for PNG was prepared, an identified the main areas for technical assistance and training including the following: ? Technical support for data processing and analysis of data collected from Demographic and Health Survey relating to (i) Estimation of Crop production, area etc.; and (ii) Food security; and ? Technical assistance for preparation of framework for conduct of Agricultural Census; and This TCP provides technical assistance and training for areas identified above, and aims to strengthen the capacity of relevant government agencies in PNG to process and analyse agricultural statistics.

This project will fund the participation of experts from the Western Balkans, Turkey and selected East European countries to attend a statistical training course on the use of administrative registers in the production of statistics. The course will take place in September 2010 in Oslo. The aim of the course is to give an overview of principles and best practices for producing statistics based on administrative sources.

This project will fund the participation of experts from the Western Balkans, Turkey and selected East European countries to attend a statistical training course in the field of data analysis and data modelling.The courses will take place from 28 June to 2 July at the Swiss Federal Statistical Office (SFSO) in Neuch̢tel, Switzerland. The aim of the course is to introduce participants into the methods of data analysis and modelling. Emphasis is given to the way of exploring univariate and multivariate data and applications of known statistical models such as multiple linear regression, ANOVA and ANCOVA, as well as some generalized linear models, e.g. logistic regression. The validation of the applied models is treated as an important part of the training.

The aim of the project is, for officials from Ukraine, to gain experience from EFTA countries on the calculation of insurance and freight values in imported goods (CIF/FOB).The project might be carried out in 3 stages:I.Study visit of Ukrainian statisticians from SSCU and the Customs Office to the relevant EFTA national authorities in order to become familiar with:-The international methodology for the calculation of insurance and freight values in imported goods;-The imputation of insurance and freight values in imported goods at the level of the customs declaration or at desegregated level of the harmonised nomenclature.II.Assessment by EFTA national experts of the methodology and tools used by Ukraine for the imputation of insurance and freight values in external trade statistics. EFTA national experts are expected to provide a report with recommendations for the improvement of the calculation of insurance and freight for the purpose of external trade statistics.III.Organisation of a light seminar for about 15 participants from the Customs Office, the State Statistics Committee and the Central Bank of Ukraine (balance of payments) to discuss the recommendations and their implementation.

The International Association for Official Statistics (IAOS) and the National Statistics Institute (INE) of Chile will organise the 2010 Conference.The objective of this project is to finance the participation of statisticians to attend the Conference on official statistics and the environment: approaches, issues, challenges and linkages October 20-22 in Santiago, Chile.

The objective of this project is mainly to finance the participation of experts in international and regional events in the field of statistics. Travel costs and per-diems will only be covered for experts from countries covered by the memorandum of understanding between EFTA and Eurostat.The project is limited to the participation of maximum 20 experts in international and regional events organised or co-organised by Eurostat, UNECE or OECD in 2010. Each request, in cooperation with Eurostat, will be scrutinised in light of the relevance of the event and the financial capacity of the applicant.

The UNECE Statistical Division jointly with Eurostat, EFTA and the OECD is organizing and co-financing a Meeting of the Group of Experts on National Accounts. The aim of the meeting is to discuss issues related to the implementation of the 2008 System of National Accounts (SNA). The first part of the meeting is co-organised between UNECE and EFTA and will be devoted to the development of regional implementation plans for the 2008 SNA in EECCA and Western Balkan countries. Funding for the participation of about 10 experts from SEE and EECCA.

The main objective of this Grant is to support advocacy for the ratification and endorsement of the African Charter on Statistics and enable its implementation by each African State. The African Union Commission will enhance its coordination of statistical activities with the other partners, in particular, with the other two pan-African institutions, the United Nations Economic Commission for Africa and the African Development Bank. The main components are the following:(1) Advocacy for the ratification and endorsement of the Charter, specifically: (i) dissemination of advocacy material; and (ii) training of resource persons.(2) Implementation of the African Charter on Statistics, specifically: (i) elaboration of guidelines for the implementation of the Charter's principles; (ii) report on the baseline situation on the implementation of the Charter's principles; (iii) training on specific issues relating to the Charter's principles.

The objective of the project is to operationalize the Reference Regional Strategic Framework for Statistical Capacity Building in Africa (RRSF) with a view to integrating selected RRSF actions in the NSDS process in Africa. Main focus will be on mainstreaming gender statistics in the development process, promoting regional integration and statistical harmonization, and developing human resources through training. Specifically, the project supports: (i) development of a Compendium on Gender Statistics, finalization of the Handbook on Gender Statistics and creation of a training module by African Group on Gender Statistics (AGGES); (ii) evaluation and harmonization of statistical training in Africa by African Group on Statistical Training (AGROST); (iii) meetings of the RRSF working groups, namely, AGGES,  AGROST, African Group on Harmonization of Statistics in support of Regional Integration (AGSHASA); (iv) training workshops to train trainers (representatives of national statistical offices, line ministries, statistical training centers, research centers and sub-regional and regional organizations) on gender statistics based on the Handbook and the Compendium; (v) African Statistical Knowledge Network, facilitating exchange of information related to African Group on Informal Sector (AGIS); and (vi) monitoring RRSF activities.

(1) On-site training. This component intends to train national statistical office (NSO) and sector technical staff, mostly in Labor, Education, Health, Tourism and Agriculture/Environment, in: survey design and organization and survey quality assurance (Agricultural annual survey, agricultural census, Monitoring of Households Living Conditions, Annual Employment survey, Reproductive Health Survey; creating and managing databases; archiving/dissemination, communication/publication.(2) Technical assistance in National Accounts and poverty analysis. The objective of this component is to train relevant staff in: ERETES; SNA 93 method and updating the base-year; tourism satellite accounts; Informal Sector; poverty map; targeting of social actions using proxy means methods; poverty profile; environmental statistics. (3) Sector assistance. The grant will support the production and publication of the National Statistical Yearbook and sectoral statistical yearbooks. (4) Development of statistical applications. This component helps NSO and sectors apply new techniques and prepare analytical work.(5) Upgrading computing equipment.

The grant will be used to finance: assessment of the existing statistical system as a whole; review of the current statistics regulations; review of the current institutional arrangements for data collection, including division of responsibilities between national and regional bodies, evaluation of the current and future demand by data users in general and policy makers, both at the central and regional levels; evaluation of statistical capacities, resources, staff training needs, and equipment; review of existing survey instruments and methodology and providing recommendations on adoption of new techniques/methodology as needed; assessing needs to improve the compilation of national accounts, formulation of a master plan for the National Statistics Service of Georgia (GeoStat), including costing and sequencing, assisting with establishing an implementationmechanism, and organization of a workshop on the statistical master plan. A three step process will be undertaken to identify a clear and concrete plan for long-term statistical development: (i) diagnostics will be conducted to assess current conditions and needs, including assessment for Adjara Autonomous Republic; (ii) draft strategy will be developed to set forth a clear trajectory for future interventions both at the national as well as regional level; (iii) a master plan will be produced to operationalize the strategy and lay out key activities with a defined time-frame and respective cost estimates, including piloting regional institutional arrangements for Adjara (with potential to be replicated in other regions).

The purpose of the global strategy is to provide the vision for national and international statistical systems to produce the basic agricultural data and information to guide the decision making required for the 21st century. A grant was approved by TFSCB in August 2008 to support the preparation of a global strategic plan for agricultural and rural statistics. This project is supported by additional funds to cover the following:(1) Complete work on the Global Strategy for Agricultural Statistics. Considerable progresshas been made in the preparation of the global strategy. The work is being undertaken under the auspices of the UN Statistical Commission and with the guidance of a Friends of the Chair Group. A draft was presented at a satellite meeting of the International Statistical Institute in Maputo, Mozambique in August 2009. It is expected that the final document will be presented 41st Session of the UN Statistical Commission in New York in February 2010 for approval. The Strategy will be disseminated at the fifth International Conference on Agricultural Statistics (ICAS V) that is scheduled to take place under the auspices of the International Statistical Institute in Kampala, Uganda in October 2010, where a plan to implement the strategy will be developed.(2) Update and supplement the Wye Group handbook on Statistics on Rural Development and Agriculture Household Income as an integral part of the work on the global strategy to improve agricultural statistics.

(1) Updating the SMP and preparation of detailed implementation plan, including an IT development strategy outlining the necessary actions for strengthening the entire IT system.(2) Dissemination workshop.

(1) Updating of the SMP and preparation of detailed implementation plan, including an IT development strategy outlining the necessary actions for strengthening the entire IT system.(2) Dissemination workshop.

This project seeks to strengthen the information base for evidence-based policymaking in Latin America and the Caribbean (LAC). All grant financed activities will be developed by the Centro de Estudios Distributivos, Laborales y Sociales (CEDLAS) from the Universidad Nacional de La Plata in Argentina in the context of the Socio Economic Database for Latin America and the Caribbean (SEDLAC) project. The main components are the following:(1) Extension of the SEDLAC database to include labor force surveys. An increasing number of countries in the region implement labor force surveys on a monthly or quarterly basis. This component allows the inclusion of a subset of these surveys in the database, allowing for a closer monitoring of labor indicators and a more in-depth analysis of labor markets in the region.(2) Training and capacity building in evidence-based socio-economic research and on cross country database homogenization through CEDLAS training and knowledge exchange program on the measurement and analysis of socio-economic issues in the region for technical personnel from the national data producing agencies. The program provides training on research methods for cross country socio-economic analysis in Latin America and the Caribbean and a setting for the exchange of experiences from data users and providers, to further the goal of a greater homogeneity in the regions data collection efforts.

The objective of the project is to improve the capacity of the Middle East and North Africa Region countries to collect, treat, and analyze migration data through the use of model (standardized) questionnaires. Enhanced knowledge will lead to better management and implementation of migration policies, as well a transfer of knowledge to the National Statistical Agencies (NSA). The project activities include: (i) finalization of the Migration Questionnaires and Remittances Questionnaire; and (ii) preparation of Manuals on: a) Survey Design and Organization, b) Instructions to Supervisors, and c) Instructions to Interviewers.

(1) Legal Reform. The objective of this component is to review and revise the existing laws, to define the specific roles of institutions integral to the National Vital Statistics System, and to promote needed legal reform. The grant will facilitate a South-South exchange of consultant services which will advise the legal commission in best legal practices, define institutional roles, and determine legal divisions of responsibility. The commission includes, the National Assembly's Commission on Population (Asamblea Nacional Comision de Poblacion), Supreme Electoral College (Consejo Supremo Electoral), legal advisors and project managers from the National Institute for Information Development (Institucion Nacional de la Informacion y Desarollo, INIDE), Ministry of Health of Nicaragua (MOH/MINSA), and the Nicaraguan Institute of Municipal Development (INIFOM).  (2) Inter-institutional capacity-building and human resources development. This component will finance two workshops in institutional capacity building and human resource development. The objective of the first workshop is to train and sensitize medical personnel at the 17 SILAIS (Local System of Integrated Health Care) centers, as well as civil registry officers in every municipality, in capturing and recording quality data according to the international ICD-10 standards. (3) Campaign for Education of the Population and Information Dissemination. This component will support the National Institute for Information and Development (INIDE)'s national educational campaign whose objective is to increase awareness of the benefits of registering births and deaths in the population. (4) Pilot program for mobile civil registry offices in remote areas. The objective of this component is to train an existing health employee from a district hospital or health center in 45 of the 136 municipalities where SILAIS centers and civil registry offices are inaccessible to remote populations, to serve as a mobile civil registrar. This mobile codifador (coder), will be trained by representatives at MOH, INIDE, and INIFOM.

The purpose of the International Conference on the Informal Sector and Informal Employment (IS&IE) is to analyze the economic implications of the economic crisis, look into the definition and statistical measurement of the concepts, and study the public policies implemented. In Vietnam, the conference will reinforce the General Statistical Office (GSO)s skills related to surveys, and raise awareness about informal sector and informal employment issues. The main components are the following:(1) South to South Statistical Cooperation by inviting delegations from Africa, Latin America, and Asia to Vietnam to share experiences with measuring the informal sector and informal employment for the purpose of informing public policy.(2) Dissemination of Results. The proceedings of the conference will be revised, expanded, and edited to create materials for dissemination.(3) Identification of areas of research, for example, building a task force of pilot countries to elaborate generic procedures and integrate existing surveys into the National Accounts, integrating the Informal Sector Surveys in the survey toolkit of the Accelerated Data Program (ADP) by PARIS21, developing specific indicators to measure survey quality.

(1) Capacity Building and Knowledge Management. This component aims to build the capacity of Ministry of Livestock and Fisheries staff in the use of available livestock data, identification of data gaps and preparation of poverty focused livestock sector analyses using the Livestock Sector Investment and Policy Toolkit (LSIPT) through a livestock sector review, using the LSIPT modules and training to national teams on module implementation and analysis and validation of data.(2) Data assessment/verification. This component aims to identify key sector indicators and review and evaluate the quality of available livestock data.(3) Advocacy. This component aims to create awareness on the need to use data and analysis in national planning process. Activities include: (i) review the role of data in national planning; (i) use data and analysis as input into a National Action Plan; (iii) draft components of National Livestock Plan.

To increase business productivity and competitiveness by improving the business climate, strengthening institucionality, competitiveness policies and instruments, and supporting productive development and innovation.
The project will support the improvement of gathering, processing and publication of social and economic statistics by the Barbados Statistical Service.
To support the implementation of reforms regarding social and labor programs and policies refelcted in the framework of the series of social policy reform loans

The objective of the grant is to improve the capacity of national statistical services of the Commonwealth Independent States (CIS) to constantly strengthen the professional level of their employees to ensure the regular upgrade of their professional staff to comply with the increased demand for statistical information under changing economic environment. The main components are:(1) A comparative assessment of CIS countries statistical capacities including desk study, skills profiling and training needs assessment paper.(2) Training courses content development and pilot courses delivery. Necessary training tools and course material are to be developed and used by national trainers to train staff in different NSO departments and regional offices as well as e-learning statistical course development where appropriate. The topics covered are SNA, IOT, surveys, population censuses, statistical infrastructure, price, social statistics and data dissemination issues. The training programs for users will address various topics such as importance and value of data; main sources of data; data quality; and data use in planning, decision-making, monitoring, evaluation and forecasting.(3) A national centers of excellence support program.(4) Training of trainers (TOT).

(1) Development of the NSDS. NSDS will be facilitated through a strategic planning process that will go through the following stages: review and evaluate the current status of statistics system including data sharing/dissemination policies; develop a time-phased vision for the statistics system with strategic options; outline an executive plan to ensure sustainable development of statistics; and develop a plan to support execution, control and evaluation of the actions mentioned above.(2) Technical assistance to CAPMAS to improve the Household Income Expenditure and Consumption Survey (HIECS). This component has three sub-components: (i) introduction of Computer Assisted Field Edits (CAFE); (ii) support to sampling and questionnaire modifications of HIECS; and (iii) training in sampling methods and poverty analysis.

(1) Preparation of National Statistical Plan 4. It will include assessment of NSP3 implementation results, identification of constraints and systemic bottlenecks, and review of recent developments. It will fully reflect the new Statistical Bill/Act which is on the bills list to be discussed during current year and presumably may be enacted in the end of 2010. A country specific and costed Implementation Plan will be prepared.(2) Development of an IT assessment and an IT development plan for the Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS) which outlines the necessary actions for establishing the IT capacities of the CBS, statistical cells in other line ministries and their integration on the basis of compatibility.(3) Preparation of a strategy for statistical cadre proposed for Namibia based on already existing practices in other countries.(4) Preparation of a customized training needs assessment and an integrated training plan targeted to the current and foreseen needs of the CBS and other government agencies.(5) Change Management Program. As part of this component, a customized change management program will be developed and senior and middle management staff of the CBS will be trained.(6) Improvement of dissemination. This component consists of improvement of user satisfaction surveys, advice on micro data anonymization, and assessment of feasibility of SDMX introduction.(7) Improvement of agricultural statistics through technical assistance to CWIQ pilot survey planned for June 2010. (8) Long-term consultancy on restructuring process aimed at providing policy advice to the CBS.(9) Assessment of currently produced data sub-component will be based on DQAF technique.(10) Dissemination events.

To improve the production, dissemination and use of quality data and statistics within the framework of the 2030 Agenda f or Sustainable Development and Agenda 2063 in or der to support economic and social development in Africa.

The main objective is to increase the statistical capacity of the State Committee on Statistics of Tajikistan on the subject ' Quality in Statistics & Applications of New Data Collection Methods'.
To improve statistical capacity of Jordan Department of Statictics in measuring National Accounts, particularly in compiling SUTs.

to enhance work on the analysis of certain economic policies and performance of macroeconomic indicators through the provision of short-term economic indicators in a period shorter than an annual term.

Project 11 - Main objectives - The purpose of the project is to continue upgrading and strengthening the statistical systems in the beneficiaries, thereby improving the availability, quality, comparability and timeliness of statistical data

The project supports the 2011 population census and to make further progress in strengthening of its statistical capacity to meet growing information demand of the society. The main activities of the proposed grant proposal are: (1) Methodological improvements. This will include mapping, design of the questionnaire and its contents, listing of buildings and houses, developing of organizational plans and their distribution by communities and settlements throughout the country. Methodological improvement activities will also involve development and introduction of the quality assurance system, as well as evaluation of the census content and coverage.(2) Training. The pilot census will take place in selected areas that cover one or more sizeable administrative divisions with one percent of the total population (urban and rural). The grant activities include training of the field staff (registrars, territorial coordinators, census unit managers and assistants, supervisors, enumerators). It will involve training of data processing staff, data coding, keying and processing, and analysis.

The objective of the project is to support the Bangladesh Bureau of Statistics to prepare and approve a national strategy for the development of statistics as a basis for strengthening the statistical system of the country over a period of about five years. The Project consists of the following components: (1) Launching the process: Launching of the NSDS preparation process by the National Statistics Council (NSC), which would include: setting up the NSDS Steering Committee; establishing the Project Management Unit; finalizing the road map and the timetable; identification of the process to monitor progress; conducting a workshop to sensitize stakeholders and agreeing on the scope of the NSDS. (2) Assessment: Setting up the mechanisms needed for evaluation, information sharing and advocacy, which would include: conducting assessment of the current system with respect to staff satisfaction and customer satisfaction; conducting assessment of the governance of the national statistical system; conducting assessment of the current system relating to statistical production and its performance, including meeting national and international standards; conducting general Strength, Weakness, Opportunities and Threats (SWOT) analysis; and dissemination of information on the assessment of the current situation for review and approval by the NSC. (3)  Visioning and definition of strategies: Organizing workshops for key stakeholders in NSC, Government of Bangladesh, and the donor community; preparing report on the outcomes of the workshops and a set of agreed priority focal areas and scenarios; carry out comparative study of the advantages and disadvantages of the scenarios developed; and preparing draft proposals and submitting it for review and approval by NSC. (4) Preparation of Action Plans: Preparing action plans for each priority area, with detailed timetables and budgets, which would include: finalizing reports on strategies and creating action plans for different elements chosen as priorities; designing a mechanism for monitoring the implementation of the NSDS; designing an implementation plan for the NSDS to cover the entire period of the Plan; establishing the draft activity program for the first two years; consolidating all decisions and documents on the NSDS for reviewing and approval by NSC, and preparing this for submission to cabinet for final approval and launch of the NSDS.

The objectives of the project are to strengthen the capacity of the National Statistics Bureau of Bhutan (NSB) in priority areas according to the National Statistics Development Strategy (NSDS). The project consists of the following components: (1) Improvement of the national accounts and price statistics through: (i) enhancing and implementing national accounts compilation methodology in accordance with System of national accounts (SNA) 2008 and developing a technical handbook; (ii) training for analysis of national accounts, including provision of related software; and (iii) conducting pilot price data collection for CPI by using mobile application. (2) Improvement of the data infrastructure in survey listing through: conducting an update of household listing in urban areas in accordance with the new municipality boundaries. (3) Improvement of 4.5 through: (i) upgrading the NSB website to facilitate access to official statistics by users, based on inputs from statistical users and producers; and (ii) providing training to develop skills in maintaining the website and web based 4.5 systems. (4) Development of research and data analysis capacity at the NSB through: (i) providing training on data analysis, and poverty estimation and analysis; and (iii) providing appropriate software and equipment.

The project supports the preparation of a national strategy for the development of statistics. The NSDS preparation will include an institutional and functional audit of the CNSEE (national statistical agency). Support will also be provided to the dissemination of the strategy.

The main activities of the proposed grant proposal are: methodological improvement and organizational planning and mapping of census tracts.(1) Methodological improvements and organizational planning for the 2013 Population Census. This component supports the design of the census questionnaire and its contents, testing the questionnaire, reviewing the lessons from the first census, and development of the organizational plans for successful implementation of the census. The draft questionnaire will be shared by all government agencies and other interested organizations and will be revised to incorporate any comments and proposals. Methodological improvement activities will involve development and introduction of the quality assurance system, as well as evaluation of the census content and coverage. It will also involve the organizational planning and the development of the organizational and methodological regulations for 2013 census.(2) Mapping. This includes digital mapping of Georgia at the smallest census enumeration level. It involves receiving and analyzing digital cartography data from administrative and other sources, creating digital cartography for the municipalities which are not covering by GIS.

The objective of the project is to improve the capacity of statistical officers and academics in developing countries by providing them with opportunities to acquire relevant knowledge, keep them abreast of emerging issues, and disseminate their own research findings. The Project is consists of the following activities: (1) lSI World Statistical Congress (WSC) (Ireland, August 21 to 26, 2011): support the participation of approximately 10 people in the lSI WSC to discuss water related issues including access to clean drinking water and management of water resources for sanitary purposes in developing countries. (2) Short Courses: support the participation of approximately 10 people in short courses on topics related to official statistics to be provided by high level experts and academia. (3) Satellite Meeting on Statistical Capacity Building (Krakow, Poland, August 17-19, 2011, Krakow, Poland): support the participation ofapproximately 23 statisticians, academies and development practitioners from developing countries in this meeting to share best practices in statistical development and engage participants in a global dialogue on issues of concern to less developed countries related to statistical capacity building.(4) Leadership workshops: support the participation of approximately 60 people in leadership workshops to be carried out in the Africa, Latin America, and South Asia regions on: (a) fundamental principles of official statistics; (b) introduction and application of best practices of leadership in statistical offices based on developing and developed countries experiences; (c) organizational and management issues; and, (d) communication with government, users, media and development agencies. (5) lSI Sections Conferences: support the participation of approximately 30 professionals in lSI sections conferences on topics including user-producer communication, emerging technologies related to statistics, statistical computing, stochastic processes and their application, environmental statistics, and business and industrial statistics.

(1) Provision of hands-on support and training in managing, cleaning, and documenting data collected under the Household Income and Expenditure Survey (HICS). The expected output is a well-checked, clean and well-documented HIES dataset.(2) Provision of hands-on support and training in preparing and processing HIES data for establishing regional consumption baskets for a new CPI series. Parallel support for this exercise will be provided by the South Pacific Commission. The expected output is a set of national and regional consumption baskets underlying a new CPI series(3) Provision of hands-on support and training in preparing and processing data for computing end-use variables (consumption, income etc.), in constructing regional poverty lines, and undertaking multivariate analyses of poverty and its correlates.

(1) Statistical Information Systems. The diagnostic will be conducted to determine the priority demand of information for economic and social policy design, monitoring and evaluation. This will involve consultations with users, both in the public and private sectors. With a better sense of the demand for and utilization of statistical information, an action plan will be developed to ensure statistical production is aligned with the priority demands identified by key users.(2) Systems of Statistical Production. The NSDS also will produce a detailed assessment of the current statistical system, preferably, using an assessment framework such as the Data Quality Assessment Framework (DQAF), identifying strengths and weaknesses, and looking at all aspects of activities from the quality of the output to aspects such as finance and management. This diagnostic also should explore the 5.1 regulating the production of statistics and efficiency issues regarding statistical production. It would evaluate the relevance of the information provided by the system and assess satisfied and unsatisfied demands for statistics. Consideration should be given to new areas of information needed and the strengthening of regional statistical capabilities. (3) Coordination among Producer and User Agencies. The proposed NSDS will try to optimize the use of existing funds by improving inter-agency coordination. In particular, the NSDS will review the coordination mechanisms between line ministries and the DGEEC with the aim of establishing protocols and regulating these interactions. Management functions among key producers and users of statistics will be further strengthened to rationalize and streamline the statistical functions of various stakeholders. As part of the effort to improve inter-institutional coordination, a planning workshop will be held among the producers and users of the national statistical system, led by the DGEEC. This workshop will bring the stakeholders to the same table to discuss approaches to the development of the NSDS. It also will allow the DGEEC the ability to gauge the current supply and demand conditions of statistical information within the National Statistical System (NSS). (4) Dissemination and Adoption. Following the preparation of the strategy, the NSDS will be reviewed by external reviewers and validated through a user/producer workshop. The NSDS will seek to be endorsed by the Board of Statistics and approved by the Cabinet. Commitments to financing (and abiding by) the NSDS will be sought from multilateral and bilateral organization and from the Government (high level approval).To facilitate dissemination and adoption, audiovisual materials will be produced, as well as a printed version of the Paraguayan NSDS to share with a wider and more general audience.

The objective of the Project is to enhance the capacity of the National Statistical Coordination Board (NSCB) and the Philippine Statistical System (PSS), which includes the major statistical agencies and other data producing agencies, in formulating a comprehensive and integrated Philippine Statistical Development Program (PSDP) for 2011-2017 that will address emerging statistical needs and challenges in the country. The Project consists of the following components:(1) Preparatory Activities for the PSDP 2011-2017.(a) Provision of technical assistance, including training and workshops, to assist the NSCB in the (i) formulation of a strategic planning framework containing the mission, vision, goals, policy directions, and priorities of the PSS for the medium term; (ii) development of a statistical development framework; and (iii) development of a medium term expenditure and human resource framework. (b) Formal launching of the PSDP 2011-2017 to solicit support from high-level government officials and other stakeholders and to inform stakeholders of ongoing PSDP activities.(c) Carrying out an assessment of agricultural statistics as well as other key sectoral statistics, such as health, education and environment and natural resources statistics.(2) Formulation of the PSDP 2011-2017.(a) Provision of technical assistance to NSCB in the formulation of statistical policies, programs, projects, and activities including details of the budgetary and human resource requirements for the medium term.(b) Consultations with inter-agency committees and working groups at the national and sub-national levels, as well as other stakeholders, to validate the proposed programs, expenditure and human resource plans contained in the draft PSDP, and provide information on the resources needed to implement the PSDP 2011-2017.(c) Provision of goods to support the formulation of the PSDP.(3) Dissemination, Advocacy, and Monitoring and Evaluation of the PSDP 2011-2017(a) Preparation of an advocacy and communication plan for the PSDP to be implemented via dissemination of briefing notes, conduct of forums, and issuance of press releases about the progress on the formulation of the PSDP, the dissemination of the PSDP 2011-2017 document, and the posting of the PSDP in the NSCB website, among others.(b) Enhancement of the monitoring and evaluation system of NSCB for the implementation of the PSDP and preparation of a consolidated monitoring and evaluation report on the status of the accomplishment of PSDP activities.

These will particularly be on recording and reporting of pregnancy, births and deaths and cause of death, including use of ICD, and verbal autopsy. Also HMN will work on reporting systems and the generation of vital statistics from registration data. There will be more attention on data quality assessment and adjustment in these steps. Projects will be implemented at country level in relation to the MoVE IT initiative. These projects will generate lessons and serve as a guide in developing standards and tools and for advocacy. Meetings and workshops funded and coordinated by HMN will take place to share the lessons learnt and develop and discuss the tools and guidelines.

Track progress in health information systems (HIS) strengthening, the Progress Tracking Tool (PTT), Report on progress through a periodic State of the World Information Systems for Health (SWISH) Reports.

Monitoring Of Vital Events, including through innovative approaches, such as information and communication technology, consists of helping countries strengthen their health information systems to help track progress towards the Millennium Development Goals. It is a renewed drive to record every birth, death, and cause of death, reversing the global and national neglect of this issue.

As part of the ESCAP/ADB/UNDP regional programme on supporting the achievement of the MDGs in Asia and the Pacific, the current initiative is designed to support countries in strengthening the capacity of their national statistical systems to produce and disseminate disaggregated statistics in support of inclusive development, including the achievement of the MDGS, specifically by designing appropriate census tabulation plans, applying small area estimation techniques and creating master samples.

The main objective of the project is to meet training needs of statistical experts and health professionals to improve their technical capacity on disability statistics; provide country advisory services to support national data collection efforts; and facilitate country-to-country cooperation and knowledge sharing.

Strengthened capacity of national statistical systems, with emphasis on countries with the greatest needs, to produce, disseminate and analyse MDG-related statistics, including disaggregated data, from population and housing censuses and vital registration systems

The project aims to increase the awareness and knowledge of national statistical systems of the options for modernizing their statistical systems notably to bring a regional perspective into the global strategic body (HLG-BAS) overseeing the strategic directions in that area of work.

The main objective of this project is to strengthen the capacity of national statistical systems in selected Asian countries to conduct victimization surveys, through training, technical and financial assistance.

The main objective of the project is to build the capacity of countries in Asia-Pacific to produce a minimum set of core agricultural and rural statistics, and ensure sustainability through governance and integration of agriculture into National Statistical Systems.

The project will assist the Government by increasing the effectiveness of development planning towards better monitoring and planning for achieving MDGs. Le gouvernement du Mali en partenariat avec le Programme des Nations Unies pour le developpement (PNUD) a decide d?elaborer la troisieme phase du Programme Cadre de Renforcement des Capacites Nationales pour une Gestion Strategique du Developpement (PRECAGED). Le dit programme vise le renforcement des capacites des acteurs du developpement aux differents echelons territoriaux (national, regional et local) dans les domaines de la planification et de la gestion strategique du developpement, de la statistique et dans certains domaines transversaux qui sont d?actualite ou qui constituent des preoccupations emergentes. Le Programme s?inscrira dans la logique de la valorisation des acquis des phases precedentes. Ses realisations decouleront des besoins reels exprimes par les beneficiaires. Le Programme developpera des synergies probantes avec les projets/programmes intervenant dans le meme domaine. Un accent particulier sera mis a l?internalisation des bonnes pratiques de planification, de gestion strategique du developpement et de statistique qui pourront etre amplement vulgarisees. Le PRECAGED phase 3 sera execute suivant les methodes de la gestion axee sur les resultats et selon les procedures de l?execution nationale NEX.  Focus Area: Poverty reduction & MDG achievement.  Result Area: Promoting inclusive growth, gender equality and MDG achievement.  Special Outcome: Macroeconomic policies, debt-sustainability frameworks, and public financing strategies promote inclusive growth and are consistent with achieving the MDGs

The project ?Strengthening evidence-based policy processes? will provide policy analysts, decision makers and the public at large with an effective analytical policy tool that would continue analysing people?s perceptions on key variables that affect their lives, while based on it exploring and suggesting possible policy options that are responsive to citizens' aspirations and concerns, and support the country's general development and its advance towards EU membership. The report will systematically address issues related to social cohesion, quality of governance and ethnic cohesion, while deepening its focus on a specific theme of particular importance ? reflective of the country?s actual development and policy priorities. To achieve this objective, the ?People-centred Analyses? report series will continue monitoring people's perceptions through regular surveys, but will complement this with additional sources of data, including statistical indictors, and will apply more in-depth, policy-oriented analysis that will simultaneously look at facts and perceptions to identify the correlations and recommend effective policy actions. The Regional Project for Gender Equality and Women?s Empowerment aims to enhance regional capacities for formulating and implementing gender-responsive MDG-based policies and strategies, promote gender equality and women?s empowerment in all focus areas, and support women?s economic, political and social empowerment. Accordingly, the project encompasses a set of interrelated and synergistic interventions,  that seek to advance gender equality and women?s empowerment in a systematic manner. They seek to effect change at policy and planning level, promoting women?s economic and employment opportunities, promoting gender-responsive public private partnerships in service delivery and improving women?s legal status and economic rights. In the field of governance, the project aims to strengthen women?s leadership and influence in all areas, support advocacy for specific leadership and gender equality agendas and strengthen women empowerment platforms, supported by more effective data collection and statistics management. Plus specifiquement, il permettra d?une part de disposer d?indicateurs et de donnees statistiques desagregees par sexe sur les inegalites de genre et la condition de la femme pour la conception, la mise en ?uvre, le suivi et l?evaluation des politiques et programmes nationaux de developpement a differents niveaux (national, sectoriel et decentralise); d?autre part, il contribuera a renforcer les capacites des acteurs nationaux pour assurer l?integration de l?egalite entre les sexes dans les politiques, les plans de developpement, les programmes et les projets. The current Work Plan aims to orient the MDG reporting process with the following major deliverables:1. Production and launching of the 3rd MDG Report;2. Support upstream pro-poor policy formulation and MDG based planning so that MDGs be fully integrated in the national planning process;3. The capacity building to monitor the efforts towards MDGs achievement. This includes the provision of support for undertaking analytical studies on related topics;4. The strengthening of Government capacity for coordination, management and harmonization of external support, reducing transaction costs and increasing levels of efficiency in its use; 5. The building of organizational capacity of CSO to play a more proactive role in the development discourse, through their participation in poverty policy evaluations, service delivery and in the analysis of the proposed plans and data monitoring at central and provincial levels; 6. The strengthening of national statistical capacity, especially to better inform on human and MDGs development, through needs assessment and implementation of a Capacity Development strategy at National Statistics System. The Government of Suriname is presently in process of designing a National Strategy for the Development of Statistic (NSDS) and to have nationally owned and produced data, inter alia for all MDG indicators. The NSDS aims to provide an overall vision of the development of the national statistical system which include the national, regional, and international needs; be part of the country development and poverty reduction policy; serve as a framework for international and bilateral assistance; include all parts of the data production units and address the issues related to the analysis and use of data; follow the international standards including quality; and build on all past and existing activities and experiences. The NSDS is expected to provide the country with a strategy for strengthening statistical capacity across the entire national statistical system (NSS). The NSDS will provide a vision for where the NSS should be in five to ten years and will set milestones for getting there. It is also expected to  present a comprehensive and unified framework for continual assessment of evolving user needs and priorities for statistics and for building the capacity needed to meet these needs in a more coordinated, synergistic and efficient manner. The project aims to support of the design and implementation of the National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) for adoption by Suriname of common (in line with other Caribbean countries) data collection protocols, definitions and classifications for the collection and dissemination of social statistics to monitor and report on the accomplishment of the MDGs and national and sectoral plans. The project will build the capacity of the National Authorities to articulate, implement and monitor policies and strategies for sustainable human development, as the basis for achieving the MDGs.  Focus Area: Poverty reduction & MDG achievement.  Result Area: Promoting inclusive growth, gender equality and MDG achievement.  Special Outcome: Enhanced national and local capacities to plan, monitor, report and evaluate the MDGs and related national development priorities, including within resource frameworks

This multi-donor programme is designed to provide capacity building inputs to support the strengthening of poverty monitoring and social policy development systems in the CARICOM Region. It will build on existing statistical support programmes developed and supported by the Caribbean Community (CARICOM) Secretariat, the Caribbean Development Bank, the UN system and other development partner agencies.  The participating agencies will focus their support on inputs linked to the achievement of the MDGs and will also support the strengthening of national and regional capacities to systematically collect, analyze and disseminate social data to inform social policy formulation. The overall outcome of this programme will result in a systematic and coherent flow of donor inputs to support a Caribbean wide system of social data capture, poverty monitoring and policy development.  Focus Area: Poverty reduction & MDG achievement.  Result Area: Promoting inclusive growth, gender equality and MDG achievement.  Special Outcome: Enhanced national and local capacities to plan, monitor, report and evaluate the MDGs and related national development priorities, including within resource frameworks

The 2012 Population and Housing Census will provide up-to-date data on the country's economic and social conditions that are vital to inform the Government of the Turks and Caicos Islands' decision-making process. The project's main objective is to ensure the availability of accurate demographic data and information on the factors contributing to poverty in TCI.  It will also build capacity in the country to undertake periodic household research, develop proposals to reduce poverty and monitor the implementation of poverty reduction and social protection programmes.The overall objective of the Country Poverty Assessment is to assess the current conditions affecting the welfare of people, identify policies, strategies, action programmes and projects that would reduce the extent and severity of poverty in BMCs.  The study analyses the poverty situation for men, women, youth and children, the processes that generate and maintain conditions conducive to poverty, existing responses to the poverty situation and the means available for more vigorous and effective actions to reduce poverty.  It includes a baseline assessment of the current status in the attainment of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) with respect to the Caribbean-specific targets and indicators.

The objective of the grant is to improve the capacity of national statistical services of the Commonwealth Independent States (CIS) to constantly strengthen the professional level of their employees to ensure the regular upgrade of their professional staff to comply with the increased demand for statistical information under changing economic environment. The main components are:(1) A comparative assessment of CIS countries statistical capacities including desk study, skills profiling and training needs assessment paper.(2) Training courses content development and pilot courses delivery. Necessary training tools and course material are to be developed and used by national trainers to train staff in different NSO departments and regional offices as well as e-learning statistical course development where appropriate. The topics covered are SNA, IOT, surveys, population censuses, statistical infrastructure, price, social statistics and data dissemination issues. The training programs for users will address various topics such as importance and value of data; main sources of data; data quality; and data use in planning, decision-making, monitoring, evaluation and forecasting. (3) A national centers of excellence support program.(4) Training of trainers (TOT).

The meeting is a follow-up to the CES Forum on HR management and training that took place in Skopje in 2008 and the Workshop on HRMT in Geneva in 2010. It will focus on the integration of HRMT activities in the overall business plan and in the strategic planning as well as two more specific issues; 1) the development of HRM in NSI (leadership development, attracting and retaining young and qualified staff, Motivation of staff), and 2) training in statistical offices (in-house training, e-learning, measure the costs and benefits of training).

The Central Bank of Bosnia and Herzegovina is responsible for compiling government finance statistics (GFS) in BiH. This is done in accordance with the IMF guidelines GFSM 2001. Currently transactions on revenues, expense and non-financial assets are being compiled and published. An important next step in further developing GFS in BiH is to establish a financial balance sheet for the general government. A financial balance sheet would be of high importance for analyses of the public finances in BiH, and in particular because BiH is still in a phase of reconstruction a coherent overview according to international standards of its financial situation would be important. Statistics Norway possesses both the experience and expertise to provide support to BiH in order to successfully develop a financial balance sheet for the general government. EFTA has free trade agreements with several countries on the Western Balkan, and has currently ongoing negotiations with BiH.

Reliable information on prices and their development is essential for the conduct of policies in many areas. Therefore, good price statistics is a pre-condition of a statistical system. The course will cover basic areas in the production of CPI.

The objective of this project is mainly to finance the participation of experts in international and regional events in the field of statistics. Travel costs and per-diems will only be covered for participants from countries covered by the memorandum of understanding between EFTA and Eurostat and experts to contribute as lecturers in their field of expertise.

The aim of the course is to familiarise participants with the fundamental principles and main methods of survey sampling. -Basic concepts of survey sampling-Simple random sampling-Use of auxiliary information -Stratified, cluster and multi-stage sampling -Ratio and regression estimators -Post stratification and calibration-Introduction to the problems, effects and treatment of non-responseThe expected outcome is a basic understanding of the fundamental principles and main methods of survey sampling. The course is based on lectures and practical exercises, for which computers and the SAS Enterprise Guide software are used.

The Hellenic Statistical Authority (ELSTAT) and Eurostat will organise the 2012 Conference. The Quality conferences started in 2001 when the first Conference was held in Stockholm to develop further the conclusions of the Leadership Group on Quality. They have since been organised biennially, the last time in Q2010 in Helsinki.The Q2012 Conference will offer participants a unique platform for high-level discussions on various types of quality issues and methodological aspects of statistical production. Q2012 will in particular focus on improving quality by the re-engineering of statistical systems and the innovations in the area of quality.

Improving energy statistics by setting up a national system of administrative registers on energy usage and to develop management information system which coordinates the information with the national and international institutions

Main objectives - The overall objective of this project is to provide reliable information for the implementation of efficient agricultural policies and to establish a sustainable data collection system in compliance with EU requirements. The project particularly aims at upgrading the Agricultural Statistical System of Turkey, according to EU standards, on the methodology and quality of compiling and processing statistical information.

Main objectives - The overall objective of this project is to provide adequate statistical data and analysis, in the field of education, for the purposes of facilitating policy decisions towards implementation of the pre-accession strategy and the adoption of the acquis. The specific purpose is to upgrade the data collection system of the Ministry of National Education in the area of education according to EU standards. The plan is to develop a system which will: i) enable all beneficiaries to get reliable, coherent data on finance, personnel, student enrolment, graduations and drop outs; ii) align with national and international definitions and which iii) will be the main source in their decision-making process, by the 1st Quarter of 2010.

Main objectives - This project aims to contribute to the harmonisation of the acquis in the area of statistics by establishing a statistical system in the Ministry of Labour and Social Security (MoLSS) providing required statistical data on the employment, labour market and social inclusion sectors. Through this project the statistical collection and management system of the MoLSS will be upgraded and the qualifications of staff working on IT and statistics will be improved.
To increase availability of up-to-date population data disaggregated by age and gender forDevelopment planning, decision-making and monitoring progress at national and sub-national levels

(i) Strengthening the management of the Togo statistical system through: (a) the establishment of a National Statistical Committee and, (b) an Independent Statistical Institute (as foreseen by the new Act) and, (ii) to (c) Produce statistics in accordance with priorities identified in the National Statistical Master Plan and (d) publish these on the DGSCN website and otherwise.
Overall objective is to support the development of Madagascar national statistical system and the production and dissemination of timely, reliable and relevant data.
I. NSS Strategic DevelopmentII. Dissemination and Access to DataIII. Data productionIV. Establishing a Training School

The main development objective is to improve the dissemination of national statistics in Vietnam. This includes developing systems for timely, accurate, and reliable dissemination of national indicators, and also for making data from national censuses and surveys available for use across the government, academia, and the private sector.

The main objective is to foster evidence-based policy making in the agricultural sector. For this purpose this grant will support the first agricultural census since independence in 1990. The 2014 agricultural census will be conducted after the 2013 pilot census.

The purpose of this project is to help State Statistical Committee (SSC) to create metadata systems which will improve efficiency and capacity of national statistical system. Main beneficiaries of the project will be users of statistical data (international organizations, policy makers, managers at Statistical Office, researchers, etc.). The project will contribute to the improvement of the Committee's statistical information system, web pages, and better and easy access to the data for the end users. Moreover, functioning metadata system and creation of international standards as SDMX (Statistical Data and Metadata Exchange) and GSBPM (Generic Statistical Business Process Models) will contribute to further development of statistical data. Application of the modern technologies will help to convert #passive# data into #active# data, and will lead to automation and industrialization of processes.

The development objective of the project is to assist Jordan to address its data and analytical needs for planning, decision-making and monitoring purposes, while building sustainable statistical capacity at the Department of Statistics (DOS).

The grant's development objective is to strengthen capacity of the Statistics Division of the Department of National Planning (DNP) in the priority areas identified by the National Statistics Development Strategy (NSDS). It aims at enabling Maldives to address the data needs for planning, decision-making and monitoring purposes, while building sustainable statistical capacity at DNP.In this context the grant will support the following activities:(i) to develop Country's household surveys strategy, instruments and sample design;(ii) to build capacity on survey methodology, poverty and data analysis;(iii) to improve data dissemination and data archiving.

The main objective of this Grant is to develop educational indicators and build capabilities to interpret statistics related to compulsory education. The project aims to enhance existing statistical systems in El Salvador to improve the collection of educatioinal data by improving the existing system by producing information in a more accessible way to be communicated to different audiences. The focus on ease of access to data is also intended to build capacity among policy makers to better understand the data in order to imporve planning and research. These efforts are expected to help improve overall educational public policies and the Ministry's ability to monitor results.

This project will contribute to strengthening the statistical capacity of INE and other members of the National System for Statistical Information by improving the quality of statistical operations in Bolivia. The activities reflect priorities identified under Bolivia's National Strategic Plan for Statistical Development.1: Documentation and Access to Information: Strengthening the process of data documentation and dissemination produced by INE through the working tools for the management of microdata that allow for the incorporation of internationalstandards for documentation, dissemination and preservation of basic statistical microdata produced by the INE.2: Technical Assistance for Census Operations: This component is designed to strengthen the technical capacity of INE in the preparation and implementation of the upcoming National Agricultural Census (NAC). Technical advice for the implementation and progress of the census operations will be provided.3: Comparability and Consistency of the Household Surveys: Technical assistance will be provided to determine the most appropriate strategies to ensure the technical quality of the surveys.4: Quality in Administrative Records: Review of administrative records across the public sector to: i) detect and avoid duplication in the collection of information; ii) optimize collection instruments and tools to increase efficiencies; and iii) promote the integration and dissemination of data to increase broader use among public agencies.

The overall objective of this Grant is to improve the statistical capacity in developing countries by providing statisticians with basic statistical knowledge to develop statistical systems through their participation in international conferences, workshops and short courses. The grant will be used to cover travel and accommodation costs of selected conference participants fromdeveloping countries to attend several events in 2013-2014 that will be taking place under the auspices of the International Statistical Institute (ISI).

The main objective is to update the Liberia's National Strategy for the Development of Statistics (NSDS) that was approved in 2008 to align with the second PRS (Agenda for Transformation) and prepare an implementation plan for the strategy with costing.

The main Development Objective of the grant is to assist the Central Statistical Organization (CSO) of Yemen in the preparation,implementation, and analysis of the 2013-14 Household Budget Survey (HBS).The grant will finance the following activities:1) Assessment of the draft survey questionnaire for the HBS and recommendations for improvement;2) Updating of the Sampling Frame;3) Training of the field workers and team leaders who will carry-out the survey;4) Development of the data entry system;5) Training on the data processing system (data entry, cleaning, etc).;6) Data management and capacity building.

The two main objectives of the project are:(i) To support client countries wishing to adopt an Open Government Data (OGD) initiative either at the national,sub-national, or sector levels.(ii) To understand the particular challenges faced by National Statistics Offices (NSOs) in joining Open Datainitiatives and support them in addressing those challenges, with emphasis in the Information Technology aspects.

The overall objective is to strengthen the capacity of the Chad national statistical system to produce and analyze statistical data that is reliable, relevant and timely for development policy management.

This information is intended to assist policy makers and program managers in evaluating and designing programs and strategies for improving health and family planning services in the country.

To review and evaluate the system of tourism data and statistics in Uzbekistan and prepare a strategic plan for the short and long term development of tourism statistics and a Tourism Satellite Account.

To deliver technical assistance to the Autonomous Republic of Crimea (ARC) to undertake an analysis of the ARC's system of tourism statistics for the provision of technical and policy recommendations for its further strengthening. Additionally, the project delivered training to central and regional government officials on international standards and methodologies on tourism statistics.

To assist the Government of the Republic of South Sudan in making rational and fact-based decisions, using timely and reliable food security information. According to UNAIDS, Lesotho ranks third among the countries with the highest adult HIV prevalence in the world with 23 percent of those aged between 15 to 49 living with HIV. Another indicator of the seriousness of the situation is the rising number of orphans and other vulnerable children (OVC) to over 220,000, most of them orphans impacted by AIDS. The overall goal of the Round 9 program is to prevent the spread of HIV and mitigate the impact of AIDS among orphans and OVC. The program will support orphans and OVC by providing bursaries secondary-school aged OVC in each of the five years. The program will also strengthen the national monitoring and evaluation systems that are linked to the National OVC Strategic Plan. In line with the gaps identified under the Global Fund Round 7 HIV/AIDS grant, this Program will also support data collection, management and quality, operational research programs, and the revised OVC situational analysis.
